(4)	Private clubs, not in fact open to the public, which incident to their primary purpose or purposes provide lodging, which they own or operate for other than a commercial purpose, to their members or give preference to their members; 
(5)	With respect to discrimination based on sex, the rental or leasing of housing accommodations in single-sex dormitory property; and 
(6)	The sale, rental, exchange, or lease of commercial real estate. For the purposes of this chapter, commercial real estate means real property which is not intended for residential use. 
(g)	No provision of this chapter requires that a dwelling be made available to a person whose tenancy would constitute a direct threat to the health or safety of other persons or whose tenancy would result in substantial physical damage to the property of others. 
(h)	No provision of this chapter limits the applicability of any reasonable local or state restrictions regarding the maximum number of occupants permitted to occupy a dwelling unit. 
(i)	Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to nullify any provisions of the North Carolina Building Code applicable to the construction of residential housing for the handicapped. 
(j)	No provision of this chapter regarding familial status applies with respect to housing for older persons. "Housing for older persons" means housing: 
(1)	Provided under any state or federal program specifically designed and operated to assist elderly persons as defined in the program; 
(2)	Intended for and solely occupied by person 62 years or older. Housing satisfies the requirements of this subsection even though there are persons residing in such housing on September 13, 1988, who are under 62 years of age, provided that all new occupants after September 13, 1988, are 62 years or older; or 
(3)	Intended for and operated for occupancy by at least one person 55 years of age or older per unit as shown by such factors as (i) the existence of significant facilities and services specifically designed to meet the physical and social needs of older persons or, if this is not practicable, that the housing provides important housing opportunities for older persons, (ii) at least 80 percent of the units are occupied by at least one person 55 years of age or older per unit; and (iii) the publication of and adherence to policies and procedures which demonstrate an intent by the owner or manager to provide housing for persons 55 years or older. Housing satisfies the requirements of this subsection even though on September 13, 1988, under 80 percent of the units in the housing facility are occupied by at least one person 55 years or older per unit, provided that 80 percent of the units that are occupied by new tenants after September 13, 1988, are occupied by at least one person 55 years or older per unit until such time as 80 percent of all the units in the housing facility are occupied by at least one person 55 years or older. Housing facilities newly constructed for first occupancy after March 12, 1989, shall satisfy the requirements of this subsection if (i) when 25 percent of the units are occupied, 80 percent of the occupied units are occupied by at least one person 55 years or older, and thereafter (ii) 80 percent of all newly occupied units are occupied by at least one person 55 years or older until such time as 80 percent of all the units in the housing facility are occupied by at least one person 55 years of age or older. 
Housing satisfies the requirements of subsections (2) and (3) of this subsection even though there are units occupied by employees of the housing facility who are under the minimum age or family members of the employees residing in the same unit who are under the minimum age, provided the employees perform substantial duties directly related to the management of the housing. 
(Code 1972, § 10A-3; Ord. No. 80.29, § 3) 
Sec. 42-4. - Handling of complaints. 
(a)	Any person who contends that the provisions of this chapter have been violated may file a written complaint under oath with the city zoning administrator, hereby designated as the officer with whom such complaints shall be filed. Within a reasonable time after the complaint has been filed, the administrator shall make a determination of the merits and reasonableness of the complaint, and shall attempt to adjust the grievance between the parties. The administrator will report all findings to the council. 
(b)	The council will serve as the fair housing board. The council shall adopt rules governing fair housing proceedings and shall set aside time during regularly scheduled board meetings for the hearing and ruling upon of fair housing complaints. 
(c)	If the complaint or grievance is not resolved by the parties through the administrator, either party to the alleged complaint, or the officer, may appeal or refer the same to the fair housing board. Such appeal shall be taken within a reasonable time as provided by the rules of the board. Upon an appeal being properly filed, the administrator shall forthwith transmit to the board all papers constituting the record of such matters. 
(Code 1972, § 10A-4; Ord. No. 80.29, § 4) 
Sec. 42-5. - Interpretation; conflicting provisions. 
(a)	In interpreting and applying the provisions of this chapter, the purpose and spirit for which it is offered shall be of primary concern. 
(b)	It is not intended by this chapter to interfere with, abrogate, annul or circumvent the 1968 Civil Rights Act or other laws with regard to fair housing practices. The filing of a complaint under this chapter will not preclude the claim from being pursued in any other court or jurisdiction. It is intended to offer reasonable persons, acting in good faith, an opportunity to resolve their differences in an atmosphere of a nonadversary proceeding. 
(Code 1972, § 10A-5; Ord. No. 80.29, § 5) 
Sec. 42-6. - Penalties. 
    For individuals or agencies deemed to be in violation of this chapter, a penalty as provided in section 1-6 will be assessed against such party or parties. Such funds will be payable to the general fund of the city until the issue is resolved to the satisfaction of the city fair housing board. 
(Code 1972, § 10A-6; Ord. No. 80.29, § 6) 
Chapter 46 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Fire protection generally, G.S. 160A-291 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Fire limits. 
    The fire limits shall embrace all the territory included within the following boundaries: 
Beginning at a stake in the center of North Ashe Avenue, at the intersection of Second Street, and runs eastward with the center of Second Street to the center of Brady Avenue; thence southward with Brady Avenue to the center of B Street; thence westward with B Street to the center of South Ashe Avenue; thence northward with Ashe Avenue to the beginning; such boundary includes the courthouse square and the eight town blocks immediately surrounding the square. 
(Code 1953, Ch. I, Art. 1, § 1; 2009-18, Ord. No. 2009-18, 11-17-2009) 
State Law reference- Authorizing establishment of fire limits, G.S. 160A-435. 
Sec. 46-2. - Erection of buildings within fire limits. 
    No person shall erect, construct, place or repair any wooden or metal clad frame building or addition or any other building or addition, the walls of which are not constructed of brick, iron or other hard incombustible material, within fire limits, or shall move any such building or addition into the fire limits. No person shall move any such building from one place to another within the fire limits or cover any building or addition thereto within the fire limits with any material other than metal, slate or other incombustible material. Every week such unlawfully erected, constructed, placed, removed, repaired or covered building or addition is allowed to remain within the fire limits shall constitute a distinct offense; provided that by special permit from the council any such building may be temporarily moved from one place to another within the fire limits to remain for a time specified in the permit. If any such building is allowed to remain in the fire limits after the time specified in the permit, it shall be a violation of this section. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the moving of any dwelling house directly toward the rear of the lot on which the same is situated, but the same shall not be moved nearer to any other building on the same block. This section shall not prohibit the building of a water closet within the ground plan of any dwelling with like material with which such dwelling is built. 
(Code 1953, Ch. I, Art. 1, § 2; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002; Ord. No. 2009-18, 11-17-2009) 
State Law reference- Restrictions within fire limits, G.S. 160A-438. 
Secs. 46-3-46-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-31. - Generally. 
    The fire department personnel shall consist of a fire chief, such other full-time officers and other paid personnel as may from time to time be employed by the city, and volunteers. 
(Code 1972, § 2-30(b); Ord. No. 91.60, § 1, 12-10-1991) 
State Law reference- Appointment and duties of fire chief, G.S. 160A-291, 160A-292. 
Sec. 46-32. - Boarding fire trucks. 
    No person shall get on the city's fire engine, truck or hose reel when an alarm of fire is sounded or between the time of the alarm and the time the engine, reel or truck shall be returned at the place of keeping the same; provided, that this section shall not apply to members of the fire company or persons invited to assist by members of the fire company, police officers or the city manager. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 15; Code 1972, § 12-8) 
Sec. 46-33. - Tampering with equipment or entering storage building. 
    No person shall enter any building or place kept for storing or keeping any apparatus or appliances used or kept by the city for fighting fire nor shall handle, tamper with, remove or in any way injure any hose, reel, truck, ladder, wrench or other apparatus or appliance, furnished by the city or otherwise procured for the use of the members of the fire companies for the purpose of fire fighting; provided, that this section shall not apply to members of the fire companies in the performance of their duties or to persons acting under the direction of the fire chief or officers of the companies in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 14; Code 1972, § 12-9) 
Sec. 46-34. - Interfering with operation of equipment. 
    No person shall interfere with the handling and operation of the fire engine or any firefighting apparatus or equipment by any member of the fire company or other person authorized to operate the same. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 16; Code 1972, § 12-10) 
Sec. 46-35. - Right-of-way of fire apparatus; following fire apparatus. 
    When the fire engine or truck is answering an alarm of fire, all pedestrians on the route to the fire shall get off of the street; all persons in front of the engine or truck and within 100 yards of the same, riding or driving any animal or vehicle, shall immediately move against the right hand curb and come to a stop until the engine or truck has passed. No person driving any vehicle or animal, following the fire engine or truck while answering an alarm of fire, shall approach nearer than 50 yards to such engine or truck. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 13; Code 1972, § 12-11) 
Sec. 46-36. - False fire alarms prohibited. 
    No person shall originate or knowingly give or cause to be given or knowingly communicate or cause to be communicated to the fire department or any member of the fire company a false fire alarm. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 17; Code 1972, § 12-12) 
State Law reference- Giving false fire alarms, G.S. 14-286. 
Sec. 46-37. - Driving over fire hose. 
    No person shall drive any automobile or other vehicle of whatever power propelled over any hose connected with the water line and used by the city or the fire department for any purpose. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 18; Code 1972, § 12-13) 
Secs. 46-38-46-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CHIEF[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Appointment and duties of fire chief, G.S. 160A-291, 160A-292. 

Sec. 46-61. - General authority; control of fire department. 
    Subject to the supervision of the city manager, the fire chief shall have general control of the fire department and shall have the duty and authority to organize, recruit, train, hire and discipline all fire personnel, and establish departmental rules, in order to provide a sufficient number of qualified fire personnel under his direction to enforce this Code and state and federal laws. Volunteers in the fire department shall be subject to the duties and control established under departmental rules. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 1; Code 1972, § 12-14; Ord. No. 91.60, § 12, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 99.48, § 2, 6-1-1999) 
Sec. 46-62. - Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to: 
(1)	Supervise the activities of the fire department under the general authority of the city manager. 
(2)	Supervise and direct the extinguishing of fires. 
(3)	Preserve and keep safe all equipment of the fire department. 
(4)	Enforce or cause to be enforced all rules and ordinances relative to fire prevention/suppression. 
(5)	Administer the enforcement of the North Carolina State Fire Code. 
(6)	Establish a set of written standard operating procedures, which shall set forth in detail the qualifications, requirements, conduct, duties and general operational requirements for all fire department personnel. 
(7)	Take charge of the scene of any fire, and the chief is hereby authorized to remove from the fire scene any person, including fire personnel, who, in the opinion of the chief, is endangering himself or others or is in violation of the departmental rules, this Code, or state or federal law. 
(8)	Perform such other duties as necessary for the proper and efficient operation of the fire department, and for the prevention of fires. 
(Code 1972, § 12-14.1; Ord. No. 91.60, § 13, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 99.48, § 3, 6-1-1999; Ord. No. 2007-17, § 3, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 46-63. - Assignment of duties. 
    All fire department personnel under the direction of the fire chief shall be assigned such duties as deemed necessary for good order of the city and shall faithfully perform the duties assigned. 
(Code 1972, § 12-14.2; Ord. No. 91.60, § 14, 12-10-1991) 
Sec. 46-64. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007.17, § 3, adopted June 5, 2007, repealed § 46-64, which pertained to assistant chief and derived from ch. I, art. 2, § 2 of the 1953 Code; § 12-15 of the 1972 Code; Ord. No. 91-60, § 15, 12-10-1991. 
Sec. 46-65. - Investigation of causes of fires. 
    Immediately after the occurrence of any fire, the chief shall investigate or shall cause to be investigated the cause, origin and circumstances thereof and, as far as possible, shall determine whether such fire is the result of accident, carelessness or design. If he has reason to believe that such fire is of suspicious origin, he shall notify the proper authorities designated by law to pursue the investigation of such matters and shall further cooperate with the authorities in the collection of evidence and in the prosecution of the case when properly instituted. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 4; Code 1972, § 12-17) 
State Law reference- Duty of chief of fire department to investigate fires, G.S. 69-1. 
Sec. 46-66. - Keeping records of fires. 
    The chief shall keep or shall cause to be kept an accurate record of all fires. For each such fire the following information shall be secured and kept: 
(1)	Location of premises. 
(2)	Owner. 
(3)	Brief description of premises, whether of brick, stone, concrete, iron or wood. 
(4)	How occupied, whether as dwelling, storehouse, factory, workshop or otherwise. 
(5)	Amount and nature of damage as to both real and personal property. 
(6)	Amount of insurance. 
(7)	Cause of fire. 
(8)	Date. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 5; Code 1972, § 12-18) 
Sec. 46-67. - Inspections upon written complaint. 
    Whenever any person makes a written complaint to the chief that any business or premises constitutes a fire hazard, the chief shall have the same inspected immediately. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 7; Code 1972, § 12-20) 
Sec. 46-68. - Order to remedy fire hazard-Power of chief generally. 
    Whenever the chief finds that any building or any premises constitutes a fire hazard, for any reason, he shall serve or cause to be served upon the owner and the occupant of such building a written notice specifying the condition complained of, ordering the same to be remedied promptly and indicating what is considered a reasonable time for compliance with such order. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 8; Code 1972, § 12-21) 
Sec. 46-69. - Same-Service of order. 
    The service of any order under section 46-68 may be made upon the occupant of the premises to whom it is directed either by delivering a copy of the same to and leaving it with any person in charge of such premises or, in case that no such person is found upon the premises, by affixing a copy thereof in a conspicuous place on the door at the entrance of such premises. In case the owner of such premises is some person other than the occupant thereof, service of such notice may be made by delivering a copy of the notice to the owner personally or by mailing a copy to his last known address. If the occupant or owner is a partnership, service upon any partner shall be sufficient, and if a corporation, upon any officer or any local agent thereof. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 9; Code 1972, § 12-22) 
Sec. 46-70. - Same-Failure to comply. 
    No occupant or owner of any building or premises shall fail to comply within a reasonable time after the service of any order under section 46-69 with the requirements thereof. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 2, § 10; Code 1972, § 12-23) 
Secs. 46-71-46-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESERVED[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007.17, § 3, adopted June 5, 2007, repealed §§ 46-91, 46-92, which pertained to fire companies and derived from Code 1953, ch. ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 46-141. - Adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by the city council, for the purpose of regulating and governing the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises in the city and providing for issuance of permits for hazardous uses or operations, that certain fire prevention code recommended by the North Carolina Building Code Council, being particularly the International Fire Code with North Carolina Amendments, and the whole thereof, specifically including all appendices thereto, as hereinafter modified or amended, of which code a copy has been and now is filed in the office of the city clerk and such copy is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the city and its extraterritorial jurisdiction area. 
(Code 1972, § 12-5.1; Ord. No. 72.16, § 1; Ord. No. 91.60, § 4, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002; Ord. No. 2003.30, 7-9-2003; Ord. No. 2009-4, 6-2-2009) 
Sec. 46-142. - Definitions. 
    Whenever the following words and phrases are used in the fire prevention code adopted by section 46-141, they shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Corporation counsel means the attorney for the city. 
    Municipality means the city. 
(Code 1972, § 12-5.2; Ord. No. 72.16, § 3) 
Sec. 46-143. - Bureau of fire prevention. 
(a)	The fire prevention code shall be enforced by the bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the city which is hereby established and which shall be operated under the supervision of the chief of the fire department of the city. 
(b)	The person in charge of the bureau of fire prevention shall be appointed by the fire chief on the basis of examination to determine his qualifications. His appointment shall continue during good behavior and satisfactory service. 
(c)	The chief of the fire department may detail such members of the fire department as inspectors and members of the bureau as shall from time to time be necessary. The chief of the fire department shall recommend to the city manager the employment of technical inspectors, who, when such authorization is made, shall be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position. The examination shall be open to members and nonmembers of the fire department, and appointments made after examination shall be for an indefinite term. 
(d)	A report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made annually and transmitted to the city manager; it shall contain all proceedings under this article, with such statistics as the chief of the fire department may wish to include therein; the chief of the fire department shall also recommend any amendments to the fire prevention code which, in his judgment, shall be desirable. 
(Code 1972, § 12-5.5; Ord. No. 72.16, § 2; Ord. No. 91.60, §§ 6, 7, 12-10-1991) 
Sec. 46-144. - Permit required for certain new materials, processes or occupancies. 
    The bureau of fire prevention, under the direction of the fire chief with the approval of the city manager, shall determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies which shall require permits, in addition those now enumerated in the fire prevention code. The fire chief shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his office, and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
(Code 1972, § 12-5.6; Ord. No. 72.16, § 13; Ord. No. 91.60, § 8, 12-10-1991) 
Sec. 46-145. - Appeal of decision of fire chief. 
    Whenever the fire chief shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the fire prevention code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the fire prevention code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the fire chief to the council within 30 days from the date of the decision appealed. 
(Code 1972, § 12-5.7; Ord. No. 72.16, § 12; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002) 
Sec. 46-146. - Routes for transportation of explosives and blasting agents. 
    The routes referred to in Volume V of the North Carolina State Building Code for vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents are hereby established as follows: Only those streets and routes designated by the fire chief. 
(Code 1972, § 12-5.11; Ord. No. 72.16, § 7; Ord. No. 91.60, § 9, 12-10-1991) 
Sec. 46-147. - Routes for transportation of hazardous chemicals and other dangerous articles. 
    The routes referred to in Volume V of the North Carolina State Building Code for vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals and other dangerous articles are hereby established as follows: Only those streets and routes designated by the fire chief. 
(Code 1972, § 12-5.12; Ord. No. 72.16, § 8; Ord. No. 91.60, § 10, 12-10-1991) 
Sec. 46-148. - Fire lanes. 
(a)	Required. In accordance with the provisions of the state fire code, the fire chief shall have the authority to designate fire lanes, also known as fire apparatus access roads, necessary for fire apparatus accessibility. 
(b)	Marking. All designated fire lanes, also known as fire apparatus access roads, shall be marked, as specified by the fire chief or his designee, adjacent to the fire lane at the beginning and end of the fire lane perimeter. Additional signs shall be posted at intervals not exceeding 75 feet. 
(c)	Obstruction prohibited. All fire lanes, also known as fire apparatus access roads, previously designated shall remain in effect. The parking of motor vehicles or otherwise obstructing a required fire lane is hereby prohibited. 
(d)	Enforcement. Fire inspectors are authorized to issue citations for violation of this section while on duty. 
(Code 1972, § 12-5.13; Ord. No. 72.16, § 9; Ord. No. 91.60, § 11, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 94.35, § 1, 8-2-1994) 
Sec. 46-149. - Penalties. 
(a)	Any violation of any of the provisions of article I of this chapter or this article shall subject the offender to a civil penalty in the amount of $50.00. Every violator shall be issued a written citation, which must be paid within 72 hours. 
(b)	Each day's continuing violation shall be a separate and distinct offense. 
(c)	Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, provisions of this chapter may be enforced through equitable remedies issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(d)	In addition to or in lieu of remedies authorized in subsections (a) and (c) of this section, any violation of this chapter may be prosecuted as a misdemeanor or otherwise in accordance with G.S. 160A-175. 
(Code 1972, § 12-5.14; Ord. No. 72.16, § 14; Ord. No. 86.7, § 5) 
Secs. 46-150-46-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIRE HAZARDS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Removal of dangerous materials from premises, G.S. 69-4. 

Sec. 46-171. - Accumulation of combustible material prohibited. 
    No person shall allow wood shavings, loose cotton, waste paper, rags or other equally combustible material to accumulate in such quantities in or near any building as to endanger any building or other property by fire. After one day's notice from the local inspector or any city officer, each day shall constitute a distinct offense until the same shall be removed. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 3, § 3; Code 1972, § 12-27) 
Sec. 46-172. - Daily removal of certain material required. 
    No person making, using, storing or having charge or control of any shavings, excelsior, rubbish, sacks, bags, litter or combustible trash or waste, shall fail, neglect, or refuse at the close of each day to cause all such material which is not compactly baled and stacked in an orderly manner to be removed from the premises or stored in noncombustible containers. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 3, § 5; Code 1972, § 12-28) 
State Law reference- Regulation of inflammable material, G.S. 160A-183. 
Sec. 46-173. - Defective chimneys, furnaces, etc. 
    Any person having an unsafe or a defective furnace, smokestack, chimney, flue or building shall have the same removed or repaired, any anyone, who fails to have the same removed or repaired or who uses any such defective or unsafe furnace, smokestack, chimney, flue or building after notice given by the fire inspector, the mayor or other person authorized thereto, shall pay a penalty for each offense. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 3, § 6; Code 1972, § 12-29) 
Sec. 46-174. - Obstructions on fire escapes prohibited. 
    No person shall, at any time, place an encumbrance of any kind before or upon any fire escape, balcony or ladder intended as a means of escape from fire. Every member of the police and fire department who discovers a fire escape encumbered in any manner, shall forthwith report the same through his department channels to the chief of the fire department, who shall immediately notify the owner or tenant to remove such encumbrance. The same shall thereupon be removed immediately. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 3, § 7; Code 1972, § 12-30) 
Sec. 46-175. - Removal of unused utility wires. 
    No electric light, telegraph or telephone company shall permit any of its disconnected, dead or unused wires to hang or remain on any pole, tree or house where the same have been formerly connected and in use. All such wires shall be taken down and removed immediately upon notice by the city manager. The chief of the fire department shall notify the city manager whenever he has knowledge of such existing conditions. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 3, § 12; Code 1972, § 12-35) 
Sec. 46-176. - Burned utility poles to be scraped or removed. 
    No telephone, telegraph or electric light company shall allow any pole belonging to such company, which has been charred by fire, to remain in such condition longer than ten days from the time of the fire. All such poles shall be scraped or removed. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 3, § 13; Code 1972, § 12-36) 
Sec. 46-177. - Open burning. 
(a)	Prohibited; exceptions. 
(1)	Except as provided in this article, no person shall cause, allow or permit in the city the burning of any combustible material outside an industrial, commercial business building, dwelling house or outbuilding. 
(2)	Subject to all applicable laws, rules and regulations of the state environmental management commission, the following types of outside burning or fires are excepted from the provisions of subsection (a)(1) of the section and are permitted: 
a.	Fires contained in portable or stationary outside grills using charcoal, wood, coal or bottled gas for recreational cooking. 
b.	Campfires used solely for cooking and other recreational purposes, for ceremonial occasions or for human warmth and comfort. 
c.	Fires purposely set and controlled for the instruction and training of public or industrial fire fighting personnel. 
d.	Controlled fires purposely set to agricultural lands for control of disease and pests, and for other purposes of agricultural and wildlife management practices acceptable to the state division of forestry. 
(b)	Burning for purposes of land clearing or right-of-way maintenance. Subject to applicable laws, rules and regulations of the state environmental management commission, burning in other than predominantly residential areas of the city for the purposes of land clearing or right-of-way maintenance shall be permitted upon the following conditions: 
(1)	Written permission from the city fire department must be first obtained. 
(2)	Prevailing winds at the time of burning must be away from the city or built-up residential areas, the ambient air of which may be significantly affected by smoke, fly-ash or other air contaminants from the burning. 
(3)	The location of the burning must be at least 1,000 feet from any occupied dwelling, church, school or other building located in a predominantly residential area, other than a dwelling on which the burning is conducted. 
(4)	Heavy oils, asphaltic materials, items containing natural or synthetic rubber or any materials other than plant growth shall not be burned. 
(5)	Initial burning may generally be commenced only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m., and no combustible material may be added to the fire between 3:00 p.m. of one day and 7:00 a.m. of the following day; except, that under favorable meteorological conditions, deviation from the above stated hours of burning may be granted by the chief (or his designee) of the fire department after receipt of written approval of the state environmental management commission. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or the operator of the burning operation to obtain written approval for burning during periods other than those specified above. 
(6)	The fire chief (or his designee) of the city shall have the authority to make on-site inspections of the fire area as often as necessary to insure compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(7)	When directed by the chief (or his designee) of the fire department of the city, upon a determination that a watchman is necessary to protect adjoining property or improvements thereon, the property owner or person setting the fire shall furnish a night fire watchman, who shall be posted at the site of any fire throughout the nighttime hours during which the fire is burning. 
(8)	The clearing of ground adjacent to such fires of all trees, underbrush and trash shall be in compliance with the orders and instructions of the chief (or his designee) of the fire department. Whenever a written registration or burning permit is required by the state environmental management commission, a copy of such registration or permit shall be filed with the fire department prior to the igniting of any such fire. 
(c)	Extinguishment of nonconforming or dangerous fires. The chief (or his designee) of the fire department of the city shall order the extinguishment, and the fire department may extinguish, any fire which exists not in conformity with this article or a fire watch, in his judgment, endangers or is likely to endanger life or adjacent property. 
(d)	Enforcement. The fire chief (or his designee) is authorized to issue citations for violation of the provisions of this section. 
(e)	Penalties. Penalties shall be assessed in accordance with the adopted fee schedule, of the City of Newton which may be more than $50.00, but shall not exceed $500.00. (Ref. G.S. 14-4) 
(f)	Liability for damages or injuries. Authority to conduct any outside burning permitted by this article shall not excuse any person from the consequences of or liability for damages or injuries resulting from such fires. 
(Ord. No. 2007.17, § 4, 6-5-2007) 
Secs. 46-178-46-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EXPLOSIVES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of explosive materials, G.S. 160A-183. 

Sec. 46-201. - Storage of dynamite. 
    No person shall have on his premises or in his building more than 100 pounds of dynamite, and this amount, or less, may be held only under the following conditions: 
(1)	Any person desiring to have or to use dynamite shall first secure from the city clerk a permit to do so. The city clerk, on issuing such permit, shall notify the chief of police and the chief of the fire department, giving the name of permittee and the location of the dynamite. 
(2)	Any person desiring to handle dynamite for any purpose shall not keep more than 100 pounds on the premises. He shall provide a steel receptacle, preferably cylindrical in shape, mounted on wheels and fitted with a lock, which shall not be less than three-eighths inch steel plate and shall have conspicuously displayed on it the words, "Dynamite-Danger." 
(3)	Any person handling dynamite and keeping same in a building or on any premises shall notify in writing the chief of the fire department and the chief of police as to the location of such dynamite and shall display conspicuously a clear and legible sign bearing the words, "Dynamite-Danger." 
(4)	Upon receiving notification of the issuance a permit to store or use dynamite, the chief of the fire department and the chief of police shall examine the premises and see that the provisions of this article are complied with. Upon the report of the chief of the fire department, the city clerk shall have the right, for good cause, to cancel the permit until conditions are made satisfactory to him or the council. 
(5)	Under no conditions shall anyone be permitted to store percussion or dynamite caps in the same receptacle with dynamite. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 4, § 3; Code 1972, § 12-39; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002) 
Sec. 46-202. - Permit required for sale; records of sales. 
    All persons handling dynamite, giant powder or other dangerous explosives as articles of merchandise shall first obtain from the city clerk a permit for the sale of the same by written application, stating the time and place they desire to sell the above mentioned explosives. They shall also keep a record of their sales, to whom sold, for what purpose, the amount sold and the date of the sale. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 4, § 4; Code 1972, § 12-40) 
State Law reference- Regulation of sale of explosives, G.S. 14-284, 14-284.1. 
Sec. 46-203. - Transport in vehicle carrying passengers for hire prohibited. 
    No person shall transport or carry any explosives in or upon any public conveyance which is carrying passengers for hire. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 4, § 5; Code 1972, § 12-41) 
Sec. 46-204. - Marking of vehicles carrying explosives. 
    Every vehicle carrying explosives shall have painted on its front, sides and back in easily legible white letters at least six inches high on a red background the words, "Explosives-Danger" or, in lieu thereof, shall display upon an erect pole on the front end of such vehicle and at such height that it shall be visible from all directions, a red flag with the word "Danger" printed, stamped or sewed thereon in white letters. Such flag shall be at least 18 inches by 30 inches in size, and the letters thereon shall be at least six inches high. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 4, § 6; Code 1972, § 12-42) 
Sec. 46-205. - Certain articles not to be placed in vehicles carrying explosives. 
    No person shall place or carry or cause to be placed or carried in the bed or body of any vehicle containing explosives any metal tools or other pieces of metal or any exploders, detonators, blasting caps or other similar explosive material, or carry in or upon any such vehicle any matches. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 4, § 8; Code 1972, § 12-43) 
Sec. 46-206. - Blasting permit. 
    A permit for blasting shall be obtained from the building inspector. Every permit for blasting shall be issued to, and in the name of, the contractor or other person who is to do the specified blasting. But every such permit shall show on the face thereof the name of the foreman or other person thereby authorized directly to superintend or oversee the blasting operations covered by the permit, together with the name of every person thereby authorized to participate in such blasting operations. A separate permit shall be required for the blasting incident to each separate construction, excavation or other project. If necessary, during the course of any authorized blasting operation by any person named in the permit, the building inspector may, upon application of the holder of the permit, substitute for such person any other qualified person. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 5, § 2; Code 1972, § 12-44) 
Secs. 46-207-46-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FIREWORKS, PYROTECHNICS, ETC.[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Pyrotechnics generally, G.S. 14-410-14-415. 

Sec. 46-231. - "Pyrotechnics" defined. 
    The term "pyrotechnics" whenever used in this article shall be held to mean any and all kinds of fireworks and explosives, which are used for exhibitions or amusement purposes: provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall prevent the manufacture, purchase, sale, transportation, and use of explosives or signaling flares used in the course of ordinary business or industry, or shells or cartridges used as ammunition in firearms. This article shall not apply to the sale, use, or possession of the following: 
(1)	Explosive caps designed to be fired in toy pistols, provided that the explosive mixture of the explosive caps shall not exceed 0.25 gram for each cap. 
(2)	Snake and glow worms composed of pressed pellets of a pyrotechnic mixture that produce a large, snake like ash when burning. 
(3)	Smoke devices consisting of a tube or sphere containing a pyrotechnic mixture that produces white or colored smoke. 
(4)	Trick noisemakers which produce a small report designed to surprise the user and which include: 
a.	A party popper, which is a small plastic or paper item containing not in excess of 16 milligrams of explosive mixture. A string protruding from the device is pulled to ignite the device, expelling paper streamers and producing a small report. 
b.	A string popper, which is a small tube containing not in excess of 16 milligrams of explosive mixture with string protruding from both ends. The strings are pulled to ignite the friction sensitive mixture, producing a small report. 
c.	A snapper or drop pop, which is a small, paper wrapped item containing no more than 16 milligrams of explosive mixture coated on small bits of sand. When dropped, the device produces a small report. 
(5)	Wire sparklers consisting of wire or stick coated with nonexplosive pyrotechnic mixture that produces a shower of sparks upon ignition. These items must not exceed 100 grams of mixture per item. 
(6)	Other sparkling devices which emit showers of sparks and sometimes a whistling or crackling effect when burning, do not detonate or explode, do not spin, are hand held or ground based, cannot propel themselves through the air, and contain not more than 75 grams of chemical compound per tube, or not more than a total of 200 grams if multiple tubes are used. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 6, § 1; Code 1972, § 12-46) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 14-414. 
Sec. 46-232. - Permit required for storage, sale or use. 
    No person shall store, sell or use pyrotechnics without securing a permit therefor. The city clerk, may, upon due application, issue a permit to a properly qualified person for giving a pyrotechnic display of fireworks in the public parks or other places. The clerk shall notify the fire chief of the issuance of such permit. Such permit shall impose such restrictions as may be necessary to safeguard properly life and property in each case. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 6, § 5; Code 1972, § 12-47) 
Sec. 46-233. - Possession or use without permit. 
    No person, without a permit provided for in section 46-232, shall have in his possession or fire or cause to be fired any pyrotechnics. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 6, § 3; Code 1972, § 12-48) 
Sec. 46-234. - Sale restricted. 
    No person shall sell at retail any pyrotechnics except to a person holding a permit for a pyrotechnic display, issued according to the provisions of this article; nor shall any person sell at wholesale any pyrotechnics to be resold in the city, except for an authorized pyrotechnic display. This section shall not be construed to prevent the sale of pyrotechnics by wholesale merchants holding a permit therefor to any merchant whose place of business is outside the city. 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 6, § 4; Code 1972, § 12-49) 
Sec. 46-235. - Exemptions. 
    Nothing in this article shall be held to apply to the possession, sale or use of any normal stock of flashlight compositions by photographers or dealers in photographic supplies nor to the possession or use of signaling devices for current daily use by railroads or others requiring them, or those items delineated in section 46-231(1) through (6). 
(Code 1953, ch. I, art. 6, § 2; Code 1972, § 12-50) 
Chapter 50 - GARBAGE, REFUSE AND WEEDS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate conditions detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of its citizens, G.S. 160A-174(a). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Accumulation of certain junk prohibited. 
    In order to prevent the breeding of mosquitoes and flies within the city and to remove harbors for vermin, pests and stray dogs, no owner or occupant of any premises within the city shall permit the deposit of tin cans, junk automobiles, parts of automobiles or other refuse or rubbish on the premises. The city manager, or his designee, shall enforce this section and shall notify the owner or agent in charge of such premises to remove forthwith from the premises any such cans, cars, parts of cars or other refuse or rubbish within 14 days after such notification. 
(Code 1972, § 13-1; Ord. of 10-4-1966, § 1) 
Sec. 50-2. - Storage of refuse. 
    Every owner and every occupant or person in control of any building or land in the city, including vacant property, shall keep the same in a clean and orderly condition and shall deposit refuse for collection by the department of public works in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the regulations of the public works director. Combustible and noncombustible refuse shall be stored in containers complying with this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 13-2; Ord. of 4-3-1951, § 4) 
Sec. 50-3. - Throwing trash on public property. 
    No person shall throw, drop, deposit or place or cause to be dropped, thrown, deposited or placed, any rubbish, trash, litter, garbage, refuse, animal or vegetable matter, paper, paper products, bottles, cans boxes or any other discarded matter of any kind on the courthouse square, on any public street or sidewalk, on any public playground or park, on any off-street parking lot leased, owned or operated by the city or on any municipally owned or controlled property open to public use. 
(Code 1972, § 13-3; Ord. of 8-18-1971, § 1) 
Secs. 50-4-50-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF REFUSE 

Sec. 50-31. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Ashes means refuse resulting from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other combustible material. 
    Brush means limbs and large cuttings that cannot be bagged or boxed and do not exceed ten feet in length or six inches in diameter. 
    Bulk container means a metal container of not less than four cubic yards nor more than eight cubic yards in capacity. Such container shall be of tight construction with door opening on the sides or tops and constructed so that it can be serviced by city equipment. 
    Combustible refuse means refuse capable of incineration or burning, such as garbage, paper, rags, boxes and wood. 
    Commercial establishment means any office in or from which a service is conducted; retail or wholesale stores or premises; bottling plants; printing establishments; apartment complexes (three or more dwelling units); religious, charitable or governmental offices; schools; nonprofit organization; private clubs; hospitals; and restaurants. 
    Construction/demolition debris means rubbish generated from any type of remodeling, repairs, or tearing down of any buildings or sheds (for example: shingles, lumber, plywood, particle board, landscape timbers, wooden pallets, scrap wood from building or remodeling projects, brick, stone, concrete blocks, plaster, vinyl siding, guttering, carpet, windows, or window frames including, wood, metal, or vinyl frames). 
    Container means a waterproof, odor-proof receptacle approved by the city for use in commercial, business, industrial, residential, and other approved area. 
    Contractor means any person, not including residents of that property, who performs work such as tree trimming, yard maintenance, construction remodeling or repairs on behalf of the property owner. 
    Garbage means animal or vegetable refuse resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food, from houses, kitchens, restaurants, hotels, hospitals, etc., comprising chiefly waste food, and does not include liquid that may be drained into the sewer, or ashes, cinders, etc., from fireplaces, stoves, heaters, etc. 
    Hazardous waste means a solid waste or combination of solid wastes, which because of their quantity, concentration or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics may: 
(1)	Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness; or 
(2)	Pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported or disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
    Industrial establishment means an industry engaged in manufacturing products from raw materials. 
    Industrial waste means waste from factories, processing plants and other manufacturing enterprises. 
    Noncombustible refuse means refuse not capable of incineration or burning, such as ashes, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, crockery and glass. 
    Public works director means the director of public works and utilities. 
    Recyclables means newsprint, plastic (i.e., milk containers and soda bottles), glass (i.e., clear, brown, green), steel cans, aluminum cans, and magazines as approved by the public works director. 
    Refuse means solid waste accumulations consisting of garbage, household trash, yard trash and business trash. 
    Regulations means regulations of the public works director, now or hereafter in effect, promulgated under this article or other authority. 
    Residential establishment means any establishment designed or used wholly or in part for private residential purposes excluding apartment complexes. 
    Rubbish means refuse, exclusive of garbage and ashes, including, but not limited to, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior, rubber, leather, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, crockery, dirt earth and dust. 
    Sanitary landfill means a method of disposing of solid waste on land in a sanitary manner without creating nuisances or hazards to public health or safety by utilizing the principles of engineering to confine the solid waste to the smallest practical area, to reduce it to the smallest practical volume, and to cover it with a layer of compacted earth at he conclusion of each day's operation or at such more frequent intervals as may be necessary. 
    White goods means all large household appliances, riding lawn mowers and cast iron bathtubs. 
    Yard waste means waste from yard maintenance (i.e., grass clippings, leaves, hedge and shrubbery clippings, small tree limbs, vines, and other organic yard debris). 
(Code 1972, § 13-4; Ord, of 4-3-1951, § 1) 
Sec. 50-32. - Administration. 
    The sanitation division, under the direct supervision of the director of public works or an agent acting upon his behalf, shall maintain responsibility for the collection, removal and disposition of waste from premises in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 13-5; Ord. of 4-3-1951, § 2) 
Sec. 50-33. - Collection service generally. 
(a)	Collection schedule; placement for collection. Collection of garbage and recyclables will be once weekly on the same day. All garbage containers, trash, and recycling bins shall be placed on the street no earlier than dusk on the evening prior to scheduled collection and no later than 7:00 a.m. on collection days. Containers shall be removed as far as practical and out of sight, where possible, from the street by the owner or occupant of the premises by midnight on the day of collection. No containers of any type are to be placed, kept or left on the street for any purpose from midnight Friday until dusk Sunday unless approved by the director. Failure to abide by this provision will result in the following penalty: Residents who place or leave their garbage containers and recycling bins on the street will be in violation of this section and shall receive a warning for the first offense. Second or future violations will result in a $25.00 citation. Appeals can be made to the public works director or his designee. 
(b)	Preparation for collection; separation of recyclables. All counties and municipalities in North Carolina are required to institute recycling for the purpose of reducing the solid waste stream. In the city, garbage is to be separated for the purpose of collection of materials that can be recycled. Newspapers, aluminum and metal cans, plastic milk jugs and plastic soft drink bottles, glass bottles and jars, and other items as may be designated, are to be placed in the recycling container provided by the city. Recyclables will be collected on the same day as garbage. 
(c)	Use of city-provided containers. In business and residential areas where 96-gallon containers have been provided by the city, garbage will be collected in those containers only. 
(d)	Exemptions from curbside collection. Elderly, handicapped or other persons may be granted an exemption from curbside collection by the public works director, for cause shown. Such persons will receive special collection service at a mutually determined site at the residence. 
Sec. 50-34. - Standards and regulations for collection; containers generally. 
(a)	Containers provided to retail, wholesale and commercial establishments. Every retail, wholesale, and commercial establishment shall be provided one 96-gallon roll-out container and one recycling container per establishment unless a bulk container is used (see subsection (b) below). If an additional 96-gallon container is required one will be provided at a rate according to the costs established in the most recent schedule of fees and charges. 
(b)	Bulk containers. Every retail, wholesale, and commercial establishment generating more trash than two 96-gallon containers per week shall utilize a bulk container. Apartment complexes, townhouses, condominiums, group houses having more than eight dwelling units shall utilize a bulk container. 
(c)	Roll-out container location. All roll-out containers shall be placed curbside for collection, except as provided in section 50-33(d). Curbside refers to the portion of right-of-way adjacent to the paved or traveled city roadway (including alleys). Containers shall be placed as close to the roadway as practical without interfering with or endangering the movement of vehicles or pedestrians. 
(d)	Bulk container location. The location of bulk containers shall be so as to permit convenient safe access by the servicing truck and equipment using all-weather streets or alleys, to minimize as far as reasonably permitted excessive walking distances for tenants and occupants and to be as aesthetically pleasing as the circumstances will reasonably allow, in order to conveniently permit servicing of such container upon the predetermined collection schedule. 
(e)	Recycling container location. Containers shall be placed as close to the roadway as practical without interfering with or endangering the movement of vehicles or pedestrians. For commercial establishments and apartment complexes utilizing recycling service, containers should be placed curbside for pick up unless otherwise approved by the director. 
(f)	Cardboard. All cardboard and corrugated board shall be broken down flat and stacked neatly in piles at a site determined by the director. Generators of large amounts of cardboard or corrugated board, as determined by the director, shall provide an enclosure to prevent the creation of a public nuisance. Cardboard pickup will be provided to businesses using city bulk container pick up service or residential rollout service. Businesses using bulk containers that are serviced by commercial disposal service providers will not be provided cardboard pickup service by the city. Excessive quantities of cardboard, as determined by public works director, will be required to contract with commercial disposal service. 
(g)	White goods. All residential white goods shall be placed as close to the roadway as practical without interfering with or endangering the movement of vehicles or pedestrians. White goods pickups will be charged a fee in accordance with the costs established in the most current schedule of fees and charges. It is the responsibility of the property owners to dispose of all commercial white goods. Property owners are responsible for paying the fees for any white good pickup from their property. White goods service will be provided in accordance with policies and procedures set forth in the white goods collection policy. 
Editor's note- The city's white goods collection policy, referred to in this section, is not printed herein but is on file in the city offices. 
Sec. 50-35. - Standards and regulations for disposal. 
(a)	Burning waste. No burning of solid waste is permitted except in approved incinerators or by permit issued by the fire chief. 
(b)	Hazardous waste. All hazardous waste shall be collected and disposed of in accordance with state laws. 
(c)	Landfill disposal fee. A landfill disposal fee at a rate according to the costs established by the most current fees and charges schedule shall be charged to each residential and commercial unit receiving normal collection service. The fee will appear on the monthly utility bill for residents using city utilities. Those not receiving a monthly utility bill will be billed every six months for collection service. Failure to pay the fee will result in suspension of service. Commercial Establishments utilizing bulk containers shall be charged at a rate according to the size of the container and frequency of pickup. The property owners of apartment complexes that provide utility service at no cost to the tenant shall be charged at a rate according to the size of the container and frequency of pickup. Individual tenants with utility service(s) in the individual's name shall be charged a fee at a rate according to the costs established by the most current fees and charges schedule. 
Sec. 50-36. - Bulk refuse containers for residential apartment buildings. 
(a)	Required; specifications. Subject to the provisions of this section, owners of residential apartment buildings or of a group of residential apartment buildings in the same complex, wherein there are eight or more living units either in a single building or in the complex treated as a unit, are hereby required to install and maintain for each residential apartment building which contains in the aggregate eight or more living units, stationary bulk refuse containers according to the following specifications. Townhouses, condominiums, patio homes, cluster houses and other similar types of residential dwelling units shall be considered as residential apartment buildings. Exceptions to these specifications must be obtained from the public works director. 
(1)	A minimum four-cubic-yard capacity stationary bulk refuse container shall be required for each residence apartment building which contains eight or more and less than 17 living units, and for each residence apartment group or complex which contains in the aggregate eight or more and less than 17 living units. 
(2)	A minimum six-cubic-yard capacity stationary bulk refuse container shall be required for each residence apartment building which contains more than 16 and less than 25 living units, and for each residence apartment group of complex which contains in the aggregate more than 16 and less than 25 living units. 
(3)	Where a residence apartment building or a residence apartment group or complex contains in excess of 24 living units, additional stationary bulk refuse containers are hereby required to be installed and maintained, at a minimum, in the same ratio as set forth in subsections (1) and (2) of this subsection, for the living units in excess of 24. 
(b)	New construction. All of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall apply to all new construction, alteration or conversion of residential apartment buildings and residential apartment groups or complexes for which any building permit has been issued where the residence apartment building or residence apartment group or complex of buildings will contain eight or more living units. No building permit shall be issued for construction, alteration or conversion of a building or group or complex of buildings falling within the application of this section unless and until a plan approved in writing by the public works director, as showing adequate provision for installation of containerization of refuse as required by this section, is furnished by the owner or developer. No such residence apartment building or group or complex of residence apartment buildings to which this section applies shall be constructed, altered or converted without providing for the use and maintenance of stationary bulk refuse containers as required by this section. Any waiver of this requirement must be obtained from the public works director. 
Sec. 50-37. - Interference with containers or contents; ownership of containers. 
    No person shall interfere with or remove the contents of any garbage or recycling receptacles set out for collection. Further, carts and bins supplied by the city are assigned to resident or business addresses, and are the property of the city. They are to be left at the address if the occupant moves to another location. 
Sec. 50-38. - Limitations on properties served and types of waste collected. 
(a)	Industrial waste. Industrial waste shall be collected, removed and disposed of by the operator of the factory plant or enterprise creating or causing the same in accordance with applicable provisions of this Code and other ordinances and with regulations not in conflict therewith promulgated by the director. 
(b)	Construction debris. Construction debris shall be collected, removed and disposed of by the contractor or builder or, in event of his failure, by the owner of the property in accordance with this Code and other ordinances and with regulations not in conflict therewith promulgated by the director. 
(c)	Excessive waste. Household or property cleanups generating more solid waste than two 96-gallon containers shall be removed by the tenant or property owner within two weeks. If solid waste is not removed within two weeks, the city will remove the solid waste and charge the property owner or tenant for all cost reasonably incurred by the city in removing and disposing of solid waste. 
(d)	White goods. White goods pickups will be charged a fee in accordance with the costs established in the most current schedule of fees and charges. White goods shall be removed by the tenant or property owner within two weeks if the tenant or property owner chooses not to have the city provide the service. If the white goods are not removed within two weeks, the city may remove the white goods and charge the property owner or tenant the appropriate fee by adding it to any existing utility bill in the property owner's or tenant's name. 
(e)	Nuisance accumulations. If a property is vacated and/or a premises has a delinquent account, and solid waste has accumulated which becomes a public nuisance, then the city will remove the refuse and charge the property owner for all costs reasonably incurred by the city in removing and disposing of said waste. 
(Code 1972, § 13-7; Ord. of 4-3-1951, § 3) 
Sec. 50-39. - Permit required for private collection of waste. 
    No person shall engage in the business of collecting, hauling or transporting any waste without first obtaining a permit from the city manager to engage in such business. A permit fee at a rate according to the costs established by the most current fees and charges schedule shall be charged to each person applying for a permit to collect waste. The holder of such permit shall conform to applicable provisions of the Code, other ordinances and regulations of the city manager. Upon failure to so conform, such permit may be revoked by the manager. 
(Code 1972, § 13-8; Ord. of 4-3-1951, § 3) 
Sec. 50-40. - Removal of leaves, tree limbs and yard waste-Generally. 
(a)	City trucks will haul yard waste when such refuse is put into boxes, bags or other similar containers and placed at curbside. 
(b)	Hedge, shrubbery cuttings and vines will be collected provided that such cuttings do not exceed a total of 100 pounds in weight and are placed in boxes or other containers suitable for handling. 
(c)	Limbs and large cuttings that cannot be bagged or boxed will be collected provided they do not exceed ten feet in length, and six inches in diameter. These limbs and large cuttings shall be placed on the front of the lot with the cut ends of each limb facing the street. Removal of such limbs by hauling or chipping shall be free of charge provided that the quantity of such material shall not exceed a truck load of one ton by volume as determined by the public works director or his designee. If the volume of limbs and cuttings exceed a truck load of one ton by volume, a fee as specified in the current fees and charges shall be charged. 
(d)	Limbs and yard waste collected under this section shall be limited to not more than a one ton truck load or 30 minutes of labor, which ever is less, from the same location on the same day. Additional loads will be collected as time permits. 
(e)	From mid-October until the second week of January, leaves may be deposited in rows parallel to the street to be collected by the city's vacuum loader. Leaves shall be placed at the back of the curb completely off the street or behind the sidewalk. Property owners or tenants that place leaves in the street or on the sidewalk are subject to fines or penalties for violation of this article. For curbside pickup no tree limbs, shrubs, or other material shall be mixed with leaves. 
(f)	During times of the year other than specified in subsection (e) above leaves shall be bagged or containerized in receptacles approved by the public works director. 
(g)	The city will chip tree trimmings at residential properties subject to subsection (c) above and the following provisions: 
(1)	Shrubbery trimmings shall not be less than three feet in length. 
(2)	Root balls, dirt, or other nongrindable material must be removed prior to pick-up. 
(3)	The city will not pick up tree trimmings cut by contractors. Contractors are responsible for disposing of their own trimmings. 
(h)	All commercial tree trimming contractors must obtain an annual tree trimming permit from the city customer service department. 
(Code 1972, § 13-11; Ord. of 4-3-1951, § 4) 
Sec. 50-41. - Same-Brush and debris generated by utility companies. 
    All brush and debris generated by a utility company or their contractors in the clearing or maintenance of utility right-of-ways must be removed from the property by the utility or their agent. 
Sec. 50-42. - Director authorized to make regulations. 
(a)	The public works director may make and may alter, such regulations as expressly required by the provisions of this article, and may make and alter, amend or revoke such other regulations as to the application, administration, interpretation, and enforcement of this article as are necessary or expedient to execute and effectuate its provisions. 
(b)	All regulations made by the public works director, and all alterations, amendments and revocation thereof, shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation and shall become effective 20 days after publication. 
(Code 1972, § 13-12; Ord. of 4-3-1951, § 5) 
Sec. 50-43. - Fees and charges for containerized garbage pickup service. 
    Fees and charges for containerized garbage pickup service shall be charged by the city and paid by the customer according to a schedule of fees duly adopted by the city council. 
(Code 1972, § 13-14; Ord. No. 73.67, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 78.169, § 1; Ord. No. 82.43, § 1; Ord. No. 90.25, § 1; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002) 
Sec. 50-44. - Termination of service for nonpayment of charges. 
    Garbage or refuse service and/or other utility services, both residential and commercial, shall be terminated upon the failure of any customer to pay, by the due date, charges assessed and billed for garbage service, specifically including tipping fees, penalties, white goods fees, service charges and other charges in the nature thereof. Service may be restored by payment of all charges and assessments therefor which are past due. 
(Code 1972, § 13-15; Ord. No. 92.52, § 1, 10-6-1992) 
Chapter 54 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- For the location of various parking zones, speed zones, traffic control devices, etc., authorized in this chapter, see the official map book on file in the city clerk's office. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles generally, G.S. 20-1 et seq.; powers of local authorities with regard to traffic generally, G.S. 20-169; streets, traffic and parking, G.S. 160A-296 et seq.; authorizing city to control, regulate, etc., traffic, G.S. 160A-300. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Authorized emergency vehicles means vehicles of the fire department, police department and such ambulances designated or authorized by the chief of police. 
    Block means a portion of any street located between two intersections next adjacent to each other. 
    Business district means the territory contiguous to a street or highway where 75 percent or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of 300 feet or more is occupied by buildings in use for business purposes. 
    Crosswalk means: 
(1)	That portion of a roadway ordinarily included within the prolongation or connection of the lateral lines of the sidewalks at intersections. 
(2)	Any portion of a roadway distinctly indicated for pedestrians crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Driver means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Intersection means the area embraced within the prolongation of the lateral curb lines or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of two or more streets which join one another at an angle, whether or not one such street crosses the other. Where a highway includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. In the event that such intersecting highway also includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of two roadways of such highways shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
    Loading zone means an area of space adjacent to a curb, reserved for the exclusive use of trucks, buses, vans and other motor vehicles specifically designed to transport passengers for hire or cargo, while loading or unloading of passengers or materials. Loading zones may also be used by private passenger automobiles engaged in the actual use of loading or unloading materials, but such use shall be limited to not more than 15 minutes. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self propelled and every vehicle designed to run upon the highways which is pulled by a self propelled vehicle. This shall not include mopeds as defined in G.S. 20-4.01(27)d1. 
    Official traffic control devices means all signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected by authority of the governing body or official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
    Official traffic signal means any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed. 
    Park means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading. 
    Pedestrian means any person afoot. 
    Police officer means every officer of the municipal police department or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Private road or driveway means every road or driveway not open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular travel. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 20-4.01(30) 
    Public conveyance means a vehicle other than a taxicab or railroad train for transportation for fare. 
    Railroad means a carrier of persons or property upon cars other than street cars, operated upon stationary rails. 
    Railroad train means a steam engine, electric or other motor, with or without cars coupled thereto operated upon rails, except street cars. 
    Residence district means the territory contiguous to a street not comprising a business district, where 75 percent or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of 300 feet or more is mainly occupied by dwellings or by dwellings and buildings in use for business purposes. 
    Right-of-way means the privilege of the immediate use of the road. 
    Roadway means that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. 
    Safety zone means a traffic island or other space officially set aside within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is so plainly marked or indicated by proper signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 20-4.01(39). 
    Standing means any stopping of a vehicle, whether occupied or not. 
    Stop, when required, means complete cessation of movement. 
    Stop and stopping, when prohibited, mean any stopping of a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
    Traffic means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles, street cars and other conveyances, either singly or together, while using any street for purposes of travel. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon fixed rails or tracks; provided, that for the purpose of this chapter bicycles shall be deemed vehicles and every rider of a bicycle upon a highway shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of a vehicle except those which by their nature can have no application. This term shall not include a device which is designed for and intended to be used as a means of transportation for a person with a mobility impairment, or who uses the device for mobility enhancement, is suitable for use both inside and outside a building, including on sidewalks, and is limited by design to 15 miles per hour when the device is being operated by a person with a mobility impairment, or who uses the device for mobility enhancement. This term shall not include an electric personal assistive mobility device as defined in G.S. 20-4.01(7a). 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 1, §§ 1, 2; Code 1972, § 14-1; Ord. No. 75.97, § 1) 
State Law reference- Definitions, G.S. 20-4.01. 
Sec. 54-2. - Compliance with chapter. 
    No person shall do any act forbidden or fail to perform an act required in this chapter. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 2, § 1; Code 1972, § 14-2) 
Sec. 54-3. - Authority of police to direct traffic. 
    In the event of a fire or other emergency or when necessary to expedite traffic or safeguard pedestrians, police officers may direct traffic as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 2, § 3; Code 1972, § 14-3) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate and control pedestrian and vehicular traffic, G.S. 160A-300. 
Sec. 54-4. - Applicability of chapter to drivers of push carts, bicycles, and animal-drawn vehicles. 
    Every person propelling any push cart or riding a bicycle or an animal upon a roadway and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 2, § 6; Code 1972, § 14-4) 
Sec. 54-5. - Boarding or alighting from vehicles. 
    No person shall board or alight from any public conveyance or other vehicle while such conveyance or vehicle is in motion, nor shall any person board or alight except on the right side. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 7, § 1; Code 1972, § 14-5) 
Sec. 54-6. - Riding on vehicle not intended for passengers prohibited. 
    No person shall ride any public conveyance or vehicle not designed or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to any employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty or to persons riding with truck bodies in spaces intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 7, § 2; Code 1972, § 14-6) 
Sec. 54-7. - Entering, riding, etc., vehicle without permission. 
    No person shall enter, jump on or ride any automobile or other vehicle without the consent of the owner or driver. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 7, § 3; Code 1972, § 14-7) 
Sec. 54-8. - Persons riding to stay inside vehicle. 
    No person when riding shall let any part of his body protrude beyond the limits of the vehicle in which he is riding, except to give signals required by law, and no person shall hang onto any vehicle whatsoever. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 7, § 4; Code 1972, § 14-8) 
Sec. 54-9. - Clinging to moving vehicle. 
    No person riding upon a bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself to any public conveyance or moving vehicle upon any roadway. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 5, § 10; Code 1972, § 14-9) 
Sec. 54-10. - Motorcycles and bicycles-Riding on handlebars, frame or tank. 
    No operator of a motorcycle or bicycle upon a street shall carry any person upon the handlebar, frame or tank of such vehicle, nor shall any person so ride upon any such vehicle. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 5, § 11; Code 1972, § 14-10) 
Sec. 54-11. - Same-Riding on sidewalks; riding without hands on handlebars. 
    No person shall ride a motorcycle on any street without having his hands upon the handlebars, nor shall any person ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 5, § 12; Code 1972, § 14-11) 
Sec. 54-12. - Use of coasters, roller skates, etc., on roadway. 
    No person upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device shall go upon any roadway unless crossing a street at a crosswalk or intersection, except upon streets set aside as play streets. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 5, § 13; Code 1972, § 14-12) 
Sec. 54-13. - Operation or parking of vehicles in public park or playground. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful to operate, drive or park any automobile, motorcycle, motor scooter or other motor vehicle in or on any park or playground owned, leased or maintained by the city except on a street, driveway or parking lot provided for such purposes in such park or playground. 
(b)	Violations of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-6 of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 14-13; Ord. No. 79.5, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 85.41, § 3) 
Secs. 54-14-54-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Applicability of traffic control devices to pedestrians, G.S. 20-172; unauthorized erection of signs, etc., G.S. 136-32, 136-33. 

Sec. 54-41. - No-turn signs and turning markers. 
    Whenever authorized signs are placed, erected or installed indicating that no right or left turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of any such sign. When authorized markers, buttons or other indications are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles traversing or turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such indications. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 3, § 2; Code 1972, § 14-15) 
Sec. 54-42. - Parking and safety zones. 
    Whenever authorized signs or markings are placed, erected or installed indicating no-parking zones or safety zones, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the regulations in connection therewith. 
(Code 1953, ch. G, art. 3, § 3; Code 1972, § 14-16) 
Sec. 54-43. - Control of vehicles at intersections. 
(a)	Stop sign. When a stop sign has been erected or installed at an intersection, it shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to fail to stop in obedience thereto and yield the right-of-way to vehicles operating on the designated main-traveled or through highway. When stop signs have been erected at three or more entrances to an intersection, the driver, after stopping in obedience thereto, may proceed with caution. 
(b)	Steady red light.
