Where location of improvements appears likely to have such effects, plats shall not be approved until suitable remedial measures have been provided. Such measures may include, as appropriate to the circumstances, participation in provision of necessary enlargements or improvements in off-site drainageways, establishment of water retention and recharge areas and mechanical and vegetative means to control runoff and erosion from the subdivision. 
(Code 1972, § 23-21; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-174. - Blocks. 
(a)	General design criteria. Lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to: 
(1)	Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the type of use contemplated (residential, commercial, industrial or other). 
(2)	Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions. 
(3)	Need for convenient access, circulation, traffic control and safety. 
(4)	Limitations and opportunities of topography and drainage features. 
(b)	Length. Block lengths shall not exceed 1,200 feet or be less than 400 feet, except upon a finding by the SRB, in a particular case, that there is adequate justification for greater or lesser lengths. 
(c)	Pedestrian crosswalks. Where orientation or length of blocks or other considerations justify such action, the SRB may require crosswalks to improve pedestrian circulation and provide access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation and other facilities. Where such crosswalks are provided, they shall be located, dimensioned, fenced, screened, lighted or otherwise improved in such a manner as to provide security, tranquility and privacy for occupants of adjoining property and safety for users of the walks. Such pedestrian ways, if suitably improved, may be used by emergency vehicles, but shall not be used by other motor vehicles. 
(Code 1972, § 23-22; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-175. - Lots. 
(a)	General design criteria. Lot size, width, depth, shape and orientation shall be appropriate for location within the subdivision and location of the subdivision, and for the type of development and use contemplated. Depth of residential lots shall not normally exceed 2.5 times width, except in the case of attached dwellings or in cases where portions in excess of that depth are for the purpose of providing separation from major streets or railroads, nonaccess reservations, easements, or marshes or water areas or protective strips pertaining thereto. The depth-width ratio shall not apply in cases where the width of a lot exceeds 300 feet for its entire depth, and it may be increased by the SRB in individual cases where it finds good cause. 
(b)	Minimum dimensions. Minimum lot dimensions shall be as specified in the zoning ordinance for uses on which such limitations are indicated, subject to increases as required by the appropriate county health department for residential lots not served by public water supply and public sanitary sewerage. Depth and width of lots subdivided for nonresidential purposes shall be adequate for off-street parking and service facilities required by the type of use and development anticipated. Where such lots are to be used for purposes requiring water for domestic use and sanitary sewage disposal, and where public water and/or sanitary sewerage is not provided, they shall also conform to the minimum area requirements set by the appropriate county health department. 
(c)	Access to streets. Each lot created in a subdivision shall have direct access of at least 20 feet in width to a street which is either an existing public street or one which, upon completion of installation, can be accepted by the state or one of its political subdivisions for continual maintenance. However, limited access highways, which provide no direct access to abutting properties, shall not be considered streets for the purposes of this section. 
(d)	Double frontage and reversed frontage lots. In general, double frontage and reversed frontage lots shall be avoided, except where essential to provide residential separation from traffic arteries, to overcome other disadvantages of orientation or topography or to provide protection for adjacent uses. A planting screen easement of at least ten feet shall be provided along the line of lots abutting traffic arteries or other disadvantageous uses, across which there shall be no right of access, unless specifically authorized by the SRB. The screening shall be installed by the subdivider and maintained by his successors in title. 
(e)	Side lot lines. Side lot lines shall be substantially perpendicular or radial to street lines, unless a satisfactory lot pattern, easement pattern and area for access can otherwise be provided. 
(f)	Lot lines and utility easements. Lot lines shall be so arranged with respect to utility easements as to permit efficient installation of utilities without unnecessary irregularities in alignment. 
(g)	Determinations concerning lots for building; identification of lots not for building. No subdivision shall be approved by the SRB unless it determines that each lot or parcel intended for building contains a building site: 
(1)	Within the inner lines of required yards. 
(2)	Determined by the SRB, after review or written certification by a registered, professional engineer acting as agent for the owner, to be free from inundation and safely accessible from an approved street during rainfall of ten-year return frequency. 
(3)	With area equal to at least the following: 
a.	In agricultural districts, 5,000 square feet. 
b.	In other districts, 50 percent of the maximum buildable area permitted by the zoning ordinance in the district, but not less than 1,200 square feet. 
(4)	Of configuration reasonably adapted to building. 
(5)	Suitable for potential building use as permitted by the zoning ordinance, controlled under the provisions of ordinances and regulations adopted in conformance with the National Flood Insurance Program and without danger from subsidence, heaving, erosion or slippage of soils, from hazards or nuisances incidental to airports, as related to potential uses of such lots, or from other menaces to health, safety or the general welfare. 
As guides for such determinations, the SRB shall give due consideration to limitations, standards and requirements established in ordinances and regulations adopted in conformance with the National Flood Insurance Program, provision of water and sewerage, proposed drainage and potential types of occupancy and the like. Where a lot or parcel is not intended for building, such requirements shall not apply, but such lot or parcel shall be identified on the plat and the limitation noted thus: "Not for building site. No building permit shall be issued, nor shall any building be erected on this lot." 
(Code 1972, § 23-23; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-176. - Open space and urban services districts. 
(a)	Community services areas established. For the purposes of this chapter, community services areas are established as delineated on the community services areas map, which is adopted as part of this chapter and may be amended in the same manner as any other portion hereof. 
(b)	Network of public sites and open spaces; statement of intent. To provide for efficiency, economy and amenity, it is the intent of this chapter to encourage and promote the development and maintenance of public open space systems within urban services districts. In other sections of the country, it is recognized that the existence of assured permanent open space reduces need for formal planning for the open space system described herein, but the same principles, embodied in the balance of this subsection, shall apply where density of development makes such treatment appropriate. It is intended that, to the maximum extent reasonably feasible, there shall be a continuous network of public lands adapted to multiple purposes, as follows: Preservation and maintenance of natural waterways and water areas, protection of watersheds and water supply, schools, parks, playgrounds, playfields, neighborhood or community service centers, greenways, nature parks, fitness trails, bikeways, historically and culturally significant areas and sites of archaeological importance and other public uses requiring extensive open space. It is further intended that this chapter shall encourage and promote consolidation, combination and coordination of quasi-public and private common open space with the public land net, where appropriate. The purposes of such action shall include the following, applying generally or under particular sets of circumstances: 
(1)	To increase the extent, effectiveness and amenity of the total open space network. 
(2)	To provide protection for areas of substantial ecological importance. 
(3)	To minimize conflicts between automotive traffic and pedestrians and cyclists, and to provide for safe and convenient systems for movement of pedestrians and cyclists through open spaces not generally open to automotive traffic in a pattern connecting their principal origins with destinations such as schools, parks and recreational facilities; and otherwise to insure the advantages arising from an open space net with multiple potentials for public use and reuse, as contrasted with scattered open spaces serving only limited functions. 
(c)	Dedication or reservation of public sites and open spaces in urban services districts; in-lieu payments. Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, for each dwelling unit for which potential is hereafter created by subdivision within an urban services district: 
(1)	Where lands within the subdivision are of a scale, character and location generally or specifically indicated in officially adopted plans, 1,000 square feet of such land shall be reserved for acceptance of dedication within seven years from the date of recording. 
(2)	Where lands suitable in scale, character or location are not available within the subdivision, an amount equal to the assessed valuation for tax purposes of 750 square feet of buildable, unimproved land shall be paid in lieu of dedication. If the value cannot be agreed upon by the subdivider and the city, an appraisal board, consisting of one appraiser selected by the city at its own expense, one appraiser selected by the subdivider at his expense and a third appraiser selected by the other two at city expense, shall determine the value. 
(3)	In cases where the amount of land required to be dedicated or reserved for acceptance of dedication, under the formula set forth above, is less than the amount required for performance of the function involved, under standards established in officially adopted plans, the city may pay for the difference from accumulated in-lieu funds or from other sources, with value of land so acquired based on fair market value, as determined in subsection (2) above. In cases where the amount of land required to be dedicated or reserved for dedication under the formula is greater than is available in appropriate scale, character and location within the subdivision, the subdivision shall pay in lieu fees. 
Payments made by subdividers shall be due within 90 days of recording of the plat. Payments made to the city shall be made prior to recording. 
(d)	Use of dedicated public sites and open spaces. If dedication is accepted under the terms of subsection (c) of this section, such lands shall be used only for: 
(1)	Schools, parks, playgrounds, playfields, neighborhood or community service centers, greenways, nature parks, fitness trails, bikeways; or 
(2)	Historic, cultural and archaeological preservation, where at least 75 percent of the site is also usable for one of the purposes above. 
The subdivider shall state in the offer of dedication or reservation the uses to which the land may be placed. 
(e)	Use of in-lieu payments. If in-lieu payments are made, such funds shall be deposited in the appropriate community service area account within the recreation lands fund and expended only for the purchase of lands for the purposes indicated above, and only within the community service area in which the subdivision is located. 
(f)	Provision of equivalent facilities under neighborhood or community association ownership or management. In planned residential development, and under other circumstances where facilities described in subsection (c) of this section are provided for common use and enjoyment of communities or neighborhoods, dedication, reservation or in-lieu requirements set forth above may be waived in whole or in part by the SRB, subject to the following findings and conditions: 
(1)	The planning department shall analyze the proposed facilities as to character, location and scale to determine whether they are in accord with all regulations and standards officially adopted and in effect; and 
(2)	The city attorney shall provide an opinion as to the legal sufficiency of devices for assuring that the lands shall be held, improved and maintained for the purposes set forth. 
In relation to such waivers, the SRB shall require dedication, reservation for dedication or in-lieu payment, as appropriate in the circumstances of the case, for any deficiency in the amount of land provided. 
(Code 1972, § 23-24; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Secs. 90-177-90-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 90-201. - Conformance to Manual of City Specifications; modification. 
(a)	In addition to the requirements set forth in this chapter, required improvements shall conform to any applicable specifications set forth in the Manual of City Specifications, published by the city. 
(b)	In case of extraordinary surface or subsurface conditions, terrain, the general drainage pattern in the area, existing or probable development in the vicinity or other circumstances, the SRB, upon making supporting written findings, may establish greater or lesser requirements in particular cases. 
(Code 1972, § 23-25; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-202. - Permanent monuments and markers. 
(a)	Monuments, complying with the requirements of the current edition of the Standards of Practice for Land Surveying in North Carolina, shall be placed in all subdivisions. 
(b)	Metal markers, three feet long and three-fourths inch in diameter, shall be placed at all corners, other than those where monuments are installed, and at all points of curve, points of intersection, property lines and points of tangency. 
(c)	Such markers shall be set not less than three inches or more than nine inches below finished grade and shall be temporarily flagged or staked for inspections. 
(d)	Any permanent monuments or markers displaced or destroyed during the course of development or construction in the subdivision shall be accurately witnessed and replaced upon completion of such development or construction. 
(Code 1972, § 23-26; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-203. - Streets. 
(a)	Grading and surfacing. Streets and alleys shall be graded and surfaced as follows: 
(1)	Within the city limits, in accord with the standards set out in article IV of this chapter and as specified in the Manual of City Specifications, published by the city. 
(2)	Outside the city, but within its extraterritorial planning jurisdiction, in accord with the requirements and specifications of the Manual of City Specifications or the standards contained in article IV of this chapter, whichever set a higher or more stringent standard. 
(b)	Curbs and gutters. Curbs and gutters shall be constructed in accordance with the Manual of City Specifications. 
(c)	Street signs. Street name signs shall be installed according to specifications set forth in the Manual of City Specifications. The SRB may permit installation of nonstandard fixtures at the expense of the subdivider, who shall make arrangements, satisfactory to the SRB, for payment of any operating expenses above those for standard installations. 
(d)	Streetlights. Streetlights shall be provided and installed at such locations and in such manner and design as determined by the SRB. 
(e)	Street trees. In all residential subdivisions, street trees shall be preserved, where possible; where they do not exist, appropriate trees shall be provided, planted and serviced in accordance with standards and specifications of the Manual of City Specifications. Such trees shall be species which are resistant to damage and disease and which do not cause interference with utilities, street lighting or visibility at street intersections or intersections of driveways or walkways with streets, and which do not cause heaving of pavements when planted in specific locations. 
(f)	Ground cover. All land within the right-of-way, which is not used for structures, vehicular or pedestrian traffic, or for other approved landscaping, shall be provided with grass or other ground cover of a nature approved by the SRB. Such ground cover shall be installed as set forth in the Manual of City Specifications. Ground cover may include appropriate plant materials preserved in place. 
(Code 1972, § 23-27; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-204. - Sidewalks, greenways and other pedestrian facilities. 
(a)	Sidewalks required; minimum sidewalk width. Sidewalks of at least five feet in width shall be installed along one side of all subdivision streets. The SRB may require sidewalks on both sides and/or sidewalks of widths that exceed the minimum when such requirement is in the interest of pedestrian safety. Sidewalks along cul-de-sac streets shall extend the full circumference of the bulb with a crosswalk at the throat as indicated on figure 5-1. 

(b)	Special requirements concerning pedestrian routes to schools. Where substantial concentration of school pedestrian traffic is anticipated, sidewalks shall be provided on both sides of streets along the route of such concentration within the subdivision; provided that: 
(1)	No such sidewalk shall be required to be extended more than one-quarter mile by normal pedestrian routes from the point of access to the school grounds, except to include the full length of a block which would otherwise have such sidewalks for only a portion of its length; and 
(2)	Where the pattern of proposed and potential development is such that safe, logical and convenient routing of school pedestrian traffic requires a sidewalk on only one side of the street, the SRB may permit the provision of only one sidewalk. 
(c)	Walkways in lieu of sidewalks. 
(1)	Upon findings by the SRB that walkways, other than in the form of sidewalks at the edges of streets, would form safe, logical and convenient routing of pedestrian traffic, such walkways, improved in a manner found by the SRB to be appropriate to their purpose, may be substituted for such sidewalks. 
(2)	Where such walkways are proposed, they shall not be approved unless the SRB finds that there are adequate provisions for their preservation and maintenance, in form and of dimensions adequate for their intended uses. These uses may include, in addition to pedestrian ways, bicycle paths or bridle paths. Where appropriate[ly] designed and improved, such walkways may also be used by service, fire and police vehicles, but shall not be used for other automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, motor scooters or the like. 
(3)	Such walkways, with related uses as indicated above, may be in easements of their own or combined with utility or drainage easements, where such combination is appropriate and suitable approvals have been obtained. 
(Ord. No. 2011-5, § 2, 3-1-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-5, § 2, adopted March 1, 2011, amended § 90-204 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 90-204 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1972, § 23-28; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1. 
Sec. 90-205. - Driveways. 
    Curb cuts, where provided, shall begin not less than three feet from lot lines as projected to meet the line of the pavement edge. Design and construction of portions of driveways within rights-of-way shall be in accordance with the Manual of City Specifications. 
(Code 1972, § 23-29; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-206. - Drainage. 
(a)	Adequate drainage required. All subdivided land shall be served by a storm and surface water drainage system located, designed and installed in such a manner as to preserve public and private land from inundation during a storm of ten-year return frequency. Written certification from a registered professional engineer acting on behalf of the owner shall be provided to the SRB prior to consideration of all plats. 
(b)	Conformance to Manual of City Specifications. All required storm drainage and surface water drainage systems shall be installed in accord with the Manual of City Specifications. 
(Code 1972, § 23-30; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-207. - Domestic water supply and sanitary sewerage. 
(a)	Water supply. Each lot intended for a use requiring domestic water supply shall be served by a municipal system approved by the state, when such lot abuts a street or alley along which is located an accessible public water line. When such conditions do not apply as documented by the SRB, lots shall be served by a community water system or individual well. All required domestic water supply installations shall be in accord with the Manual of City Specifications and the city policy governing extension of water supply utilities. 
(b)	Sanitary sewerage. Each lot intended for a use requiring sanitary sewerage shall be served by a municipal system approved by the state, when such lot abuts a street or alley along which is located an accessible public sanitary sewer line. When such conditions do not apply as documented by the SRB, it shall require approval of the lot by the county department of health. Such approval shall be based upon the studies and conclusions as specified in the rules and regulations implementing the Sanitary Sewage System Act, G.S. ch. 130A, art. 11 (G.S. 130A-333 et seq.). All required sanitary sewerage shall be installed in accord with the Manual of City Specifications. 
(Code 1972, § 23-31; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-208. - General erosion protection; conservation of topsoil; preservation of desirable vegetation. 
(a)	In general, during the preparation of the subdivision and installation of improvements, appropriate measures shall be taken to prevent erosion and damaging siltation on the property and on adjoining land or water areas, in accord with the Rules and Regulations for Erosion and Sediment Control, published by the North Carolina Sedimentation Control Commission, and the Manual of City Specifications. 
(b)	In any grading or filling operations, desirable topsoil shall be conserved and redistributed as such, particularly to cover exposed subsoils. 
(c)	Trees, shrubs and ground cover existing at the beginning of development operations shall be preserved to the maximum extent reasonably feasible, where they are of species and in locations likely to add amenity to the completed development. 
(d)	The SRB may require preservation of specified trees or other vegetation in connection with a particular development, except upon findings that such preservation is infeasible in view of the requirements for the installation of public utilities and facilities. 
(e)	The SRB shall not consider an application for approval of a preliminary plat or a minor plat until it has received a copy of the certificate of compliance with the provisions of G.S. ch. 113A, art. 4 (G.S. 113A-50 et seq.) (the Sedimentation Pollution Control Act of 1973), issued by the appropriate office of the state department of natural resources and community development. 
(Code 1972, § 23-32; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-209. - Fire protection facilities. 
    All lots served by public water supply systems shall also be afforded fire protection by means of hydrants, installed in accord with the requirements and specifications of the Manual of City Specifications. 
(Code 1972, § 23-33; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-210. - Wire installations. 
(a)	Electrical distribution systems (defined, for the purposes of this chapter, as facilities for delivering electrical energy from a substation to a customer's meter and generally associated with voltage in the 14.4-24.9 kv range and below), telephone lines and any other wire installations shall be underground, unless infeasibility of such installation has been documented and the documentation accepted as satisfactory by the SRB. 
(b)	In making its decision on the adequacy of the documentation, the board shall consider the following factors: 
(1)	Terrain; 
(2)	Load characteristics; 
(3)	Reliability; 
(4)	Accessibility; 
(5)	System flexibility; 
(6)	Equipment availability; 
(7)	Cost; 
(8)	Safety; 
(9)	Timing; and 
(10)	Customer desires. 
(Code 1972, § 23-34; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Secs. 90-211-90-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - COMPLETION OF IMPROVEMENTS; PERFORMANCE AND MAINTENANCE GUARANTEES 

Sec. 90-231. - Satisfactory completion of improvements, offers to dedicate and maintenance guarantees prerequisites to final plat approval. 
    Except as hereinafter provided concerning performance guarantees, before final plats are approved: 
(1)	All required improvements shall be completed by the applicant or his agents, and inspected and approved by appropriate public officials or agencies; 
(2)	All required offers to dedicate, or to reserve for future dedication, shall be made, clear of all liens and encumbrances on the property and public improvements thus dedicated; and 
(3)	All required maintenance guarantees shall have been made. 
(Code 1972, § 23-35; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-232. - Performance guarantees. 
(a)	Generally. In lieu of completion of all or part of required improvements prior to approval of final plats, the applicant may post a performance guarantee in an amount sufficient to secure to the city the satisfactory construction, installation and dedication of the uncompleted portion of the required improvements. 
(b)	Types of guarantees. 
(1)	The performance guarantee may be in the form of a certified check, a no contest, irrevocable bank letter of credit or a performance and payment bond underwritten by a North Carolina licensed corporate surety company. 
(2)	Except in the case of certified checks, such sureties shall not be accepted unless the city attorney has made a review thereof and rendered a written opinion that the interests of the city are fully protected. 
(3)	The certified check should be deposited with the city manager, as escrow agent, who shall deposit it in an escrow account of the city. 
(4)	The no contest, irrevocable bank letter of credit shall be from a banking corporation licensed to do business in the state and having an office in the county. The terms of the letter shall include the absolute right of the city manager to withdraw funds from the bank forthwith, upon the city manager certifying to the bank that the terms and conditions of the performance guarantee have been breached. 
(c)	Plans, specifications, construction programs, etc. 
(1)	Plans, specifications, quantities, unit costs and estimated total costs shall be provided by the applicant to the director of planning, together with a schedule indicating time of initiation and completion of the work, as a whole or in stages. Number of copies shall be as required for records and processing in the particular case. 
(2)	The director of planning shall refer such plans and programs to governmental bodies exercising control for their recommendations as to whether the proposals meet all requirements of such agencies, as to sufficiency of cost estimates and as to reasonableness of construction programs. 
(d)	Amounts and terms of guarantees; time limits. 
(1)	Following receipt of such recommendations, the director of planning shall prepare recommendations as to amount and terms of the performance guarantee, including time of initiation and completion of the work, as a whole or in stages, provisions concerning extensions for cause and provisions for release of portions of the guarantee upon completion of portions or stages of the work. 
(2)	The time between initiation and the completion of the required improvements, including any provision for extension, shall not exceed two years. 
(3)	The SRB, based upon the recommendations and with such changes as it sees fit, shall set the amount and terms of the performance guarantee, subject to the legal review and opinion required by subsection (b) of this section. The amount of the guarantee shall be sufficient to provide adequate funds to the city to insure, in the case of default, the installation of all required improvements uncompleted at the time of default. In setting the amount of the performance guarantee, the SRB shall consider the difficulty of restarting a closed project, the size and complexity of the required improvements, the record of the applicant and the site conditions. 
(e)	Inspections and reports. 
(1)	The public works director or his designee shall make inspections to determine whether work has started as scheduled; shall make inspections as are necessary during the course of work; and shall make final inspections to determine whether stages of construction required under the performance guarantee have been completed in accordance with the terms of the guarantee. 
(2)	Within five days of such inspections, copies of reports of the results thereof shall be provided to the director of planning. 
(3)	The full cost of making such inspections and preparing such reports shall be paid by the applicant. 
(f)	Actions on inspection reports. 
(1)	Reports indicating satisfaction of requirements. Where such reports indicate satisfactory completion of work within time limits set and in accord with other terms of the performance guarantee, for agreed-upon stages or for the entire work, the director of planning shall so indicate by first class mail to the applicant, any surety company involved and the city manager. The city manager, upon such notification and any further assurance he may require from the city attorney or governmental bodies exercising operating control, shall then release all or portions of the performance guarantee in accordance with the terms thereof. 
(2)	Reports indicating failure to satisfy requirements. Where such reports indicate failure to initiate work on schedule or to complete work on schedule in full compliance with the terms of the performance guarantee, the director of planning shall so indicate by first class mail to the applicant, governmental bodies exercising control, any surety company involved and the city manager. Such notice shall indicate that, unless action required under the terms of the performance guarantee is completed within 30 days of the date of such notification, the performance guarantee or portions thereof, set forth in its terms, shall be called. Unless such action is completed, as evidenced by inspections and reports from governmental bodies exercising control transmitted through the director of planning, the city manager shall call the performance guarantee or affected portions thereof. 
(3)	Reports indicating unsatisfactory progress. Where such reports indicate that work initiated appears likely not to be completed on schedule, and where the performance guarantee provides for extension of time for cause, the director of planning shall notify the applicant by first class mail and any surety company involved concerning potential need for an application for such extension. Where such notice has been given, no application for extension shall be considered after expiration of the original schedule date. 
(g)	Actions following failure to complete work under performance guarantee. Where work required under the terms of any performance guarantee is not completed by the applicant as specified therein, the city manager, following the call of the guarantee, shall take such action as is appropriate in the circumstances of the case to procure the completion of the required improvements at the earliest reasonable time, according to the plans and specifications and staging of construction approved in connection therewith. 
(Code 1972, § 23-36; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-233. - Maintenance generally; warranty funds. 
(a)	The applicant shall maintain all land and required improvements in satisfactory condition until acceptance of dedication. 
(b)	Prior to acceptance of dedication, the applicant shall make or cause to be made payment to a warranty fund of an amount not to exceed three percent of contract costs, determined by the city manager, upon reports from governmental bodies exercising control, as sufficient to remedy defects in workmanship or materials for a period of one year from the date of acceptance of dedication. At the end of such year, any balance of such funds not expended in remedying defects in workmanship or materials shall be returned to the applicant. 
(Code 1972, § 23-37; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-234. - Acceptance of guarantee of other governmental agency or public utility. 
    Where all or parts of required improvements are to be completed by another government agency or public utility, the city manager may accept the written guarantee of such agency to complete such improvements within a time to be mutually agreed upon, with time for completion limited as provided in section 90-232(d). 
(Code 1972, § 23-38; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Sec. 90-235. - Issuance of zoning permits and certificates of occupancy prior to completion of improvements. 
(a)	Zoning permits may be issued for construction of buildings in subdivisions prior to completion of required improvements. 
(b)	Certificates of occupancy may be issued, and buildings occupied, only when all of the following improvements are available and as further provided below: 
(1)	Streets shall be passable for private, service and emergency vehicles under normal weather conditions; provided, that distance along such streets shall not exceed 1,200 feet by normal routes. 
(2)	Driveways shall be passable under normal weather conditions. 
(3)	Drainage shall be installed and operative, thus assuring that under normal weather conditions there will be no flooding of the building site or accessways to the site. 
(4)	Erosion protection, acceptable under normal weather conditions, shall be installed. 
(5)	Domestic water supply and sanitary sewerage shall be installed and operative. 
No such permits or certificates shall be issued, unless all remaining required improvements are covered by a performance guarantee and the applicant accepts tort liability pending completion of all required improvements. 
(Code 1972, § 23-39; Ord. No. 89.36, § 1) 
Chapter 94 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal taxation generally, G.S. 160A-206 et seq.; municipal finances generally, G.S. 159-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Delinquent ad valorem taxes to be paid to general fund. 
    All ad valorem tax payments which are delinquent by two or more years shall be paid, deposited and credited to the general fund without accounting for or apportionment of any part thereof to debt service, recreation or any special fund. 
(Code 1972, § 11-1; Ord. of 7-7-1970, § 1) 
Sec. 94-2. - Capital reserve fund-Created. 
    There is hereby created a capital reserve fund for the city to which appropriations may be made from time to time in the discretion of the council. 
(Code 1972, § 11-2; Ord. of 6-16-1970, § 1; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002) 
Sec. 94-3. - Same-Purposes. 
    The council may, from time to time, expend money in the capital reserve fund for the following purposes: 
(1)	Construction, reconstruction, enlargement and extension of systems, plants, works and properties used or useful in obtaining a water supply and collecting, treating, and disposing of water for public and private uses. 
(2)	Construction, reconstruction, enlargement and extension of systems, plants, works and properties used or useful in collecting, treating, and disposing of sewage, waste and storm water. 
(3)	Construction, reconstruction, enlargement and extension of systems, plants, works and properties used or useful in generating, producing, transmitting, and distributing gas (natural, artificial or mixed) or electric energy for lighting, heating and power for public and private uses. 
(4)	Construction, reconstruction or enlargement of plants used or useful in collecting or disposing of ashes, garbage or refuse other than sewage. 
(5)	Construction or reconstruction of roads, streets, highways, bridges or culverts, which may include contemporaneous construction or reconstruction of sidewalks, curbs and gutters and necessary grading and drainage. 
(6)	Cemeteries. 
(7)	Buildings used in housing departments of the municipal government. 
(Code 1972, § 11-3; Ord. of 6-29-1967, § 1; Ord. of 6-16-1970, § 2; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002) 
Sec. 94-4. - Same-Appropriations and withdrawals. 
    Appropriations and withdrawals from the capital reserve fund shall be according to the provisions of the General Statutes of North Carolina. 
(Code 1972, § 11-4; Ord. of 6-29-1967, § 2) 
Sec. 94-5. - Revenue sharing trust fund-Established; no fiscal year limitations; source of deposits. 
    There is hereby established on the books of the city a trust fund to be known as the revenue sharing trust fund. The trust fund shall remain available without fiscal year limitation and shall consist of such amounts as may be appropriated to it and deposited in it from funds made available to the city by the United States Treasury pursuant to the State and Local Fiscal Assistance Act of 1972 (Pub. Law 92-512). 
(Code 1972, § 11-5; Ord. No. 72.40, § 1) 
Sec. 94-6. - Same-Disbursement of monies. 
    All monies disbursed from the trust fund shall be disbursed through a special checking account established for the trust fund in an official depository of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 11-6; Ord. No. 72.40, § 2) 
Sec. 94-7. - Same-Investments authorized. 
    The finance officer of the city is authorized to invest and reinvest all or any portion of the monies in the trust fund in deposits and securities eligible for investment of local funds under the General Statutes of North Carolina until such time as the monies are actually needed. 
(Code 1972, § 11-7; Ord. No. 72.40, § 3) 
Sec. 94-8. - Reward fund. 
(a)	Established. There is hereby created and established in the city a special fund, designated as the reward fund, to be administered and maintained as set forth in this section. 
(b)	Source. No public or tax money of the city shall be used or expended for the purposes of this section, and all money received, held and administered under this section shall be solely and entirely from public contributions. 
(c)	Handling of monies. All funds received for the purpose of this section shall be paid to the finance officer of the city and be held by him in a special fund, invested in interest-bearing bank or savings and loan accounts, and be disbursed by him from time to time, as ordered by the council. Such funds shall at no time and in no manner be commingled with any other funds, but shall be accounted for, pursuant to the provisions of the Local Government Budget and Fiscal Control Act, G.S. 159-7. 
(d)	Duties and rights of contributors. All contributions to the reward fund shall be in cash, and each contributor to the fund shall execute a written release in favor of the city, exonerating and releasing the city from all liability on account of the receipt, handling and administering of the funds so contributed and waiving all rights to such funds or any return or refund thereof; provided, that such contributor may designate the criminal case in which such contributions shall be used as reward, which designation shall be binding on the city. 
(e)	Disbursement. The money constituting the fund and accumulations thereof shall be paid and disbursed from time to time to persons who shall furnish to city, county, state or federal criminal investigation agencies information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons who have committed felonies in the city, as follows: 
(1)	The determination that reward contributions for a particular crime shall be invited and received, and the determination as to the person or persons entitled to receive reward and the amount thereof shall be made by the council of the city, upon recommendation by the chief of police of the city; provided, that in no event shall a reward be paid or disbursed prior to a final judicial determination of guilt in the case to which the reward applies. 
(2)	The council of the city, upon recommendation by the chief of police, may at any time but shall not be required to determine that a case in which reward funds have been received and held under this section has been closed, and that no person is entitled to a reward, and may but shall not be required to order the return or refund of the designated contribution to the donor, his personal representatives or assigns. 
(Code 1972, § 11-8; Ord. No. 75.110, §§ 1-5; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002) 
Secs. 94-9-94-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL TAX ON GROSS RECEIPTS DERIVED FROM RETAIL SHORTTERM LEASES OR RENTALS 

Sec. 94-31. - Definitions. 
    In addition to the common meanings of words, the following definitions shall be applicable herein: 
    Customer means any person that leases or rents a vehicle on a shortterm lease or rental basis. 
    General Statutes refers to the North Carolina General Statutes, and any reference to a particular section thereof shall include the same as may be from time to time amended, modified, supplemented, revised or superseded. 
    Gross receipts means the amount that is or would be reported as gross receipts on a business's state income tax return, or on the federal income tax return filed with the state income tax return if the state return if the state return does not separately state gross receipts for the most recently completed tax year. Taxes collected hereunder are not subject to the tax herein imposed and are not included in gross receipts. 
    Lease or rental means a transfer, for consideration, of the use but not the ownership of property to another for a period of time, G.S. 105-164.3(17)a. 
    Longterm lease or rental means a lease or rental made under a written agreement to lease or rent property to the same person for a period of at least 365 continuous days. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 105-187.1(3). 
    Person means any individual, trustee, executor, other fiduciary, corporation, unincorporated association, partnership, sole proprietorship, company, firm, or other legal entity. 
    Shortterm lease or rental means any lease or rental of a vehicle that is not a longterm lease or rental. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-215.1(e)(2), 105-187.1(4). 
    Tax collector means that individual appointed by the governing body pursuant to G.S. 105-349 to collect taxes on behalf of the city and any other person authorized to carry out the duties and functions of such individual. 
    Taxpayer means any person liable for the taxes imposed by this article. 
    Vehicle means any of the following: 
(1)	A motor vehicle of the private passenger type, including a passenger van, minivan, or sport utility vehicle. 
(2)	A motor vehicle of the cargo type, including a cargo van, pickup truck, or truck with a gross vehicle weight of 26,000 pounds or less used predominantly in the transportation of property for other than commercial freight, and that does not require the operator to possess a commercial drivers license. 
(3)	A trailer or semi-trailer with a gross vehicle weight of 6,000 pounds or less. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-215.1(e)(1). 
(Code 1972, § 11-31; Ord. No. 2000.20, § 1, 7-12-2000) 
Sec. 94-32. - Levy of tax. 
    A tax is hereby imposed and levied in an amount equal to 11/2 percent of the gross receipts derived from the shortterm lease or rental of vehicles at retail to the general public. This tax on gross receipts is in addition to the privilege taxes authorized by G.S. 160A-211. 
(Code 1972, § 11-32; Ord. No. 2000.20, § 2, 7-12-2000) 
Sec. 94-33. - Collection. 
    Every person engaged in the business of the shortterm lease or rental of vehicles at retail to the general public shall collect at the time of the lease or rental the tax herein levied, place the tax so collected in a segregated account, and thereafter remit such tax to the tax collector in accordance with the provisions of this article. The taxpayer shall include a provision in each retail shortterm lease or rental agreement stating that the percentage amount enacted by this article of the total lease or rental price, excluding sales tax, is being charged as a tax on gross receipts. The amount of the tax shall be stated separately from the lease or rental and shown separately on the taxpayer's records. The tax shall be paid by the customer to the taxpayer as trustee for and on account of the city. The taxpayer shall be liable for the collection thereof and for its payment to the tax collector and the taxpayer's failure to charge or to collect said tax from the customer shall not affect such liability. 
(Code 1972, § 11-33; Ord. No. 2000.20, § 3, 7-12-2000) 
Sec. 94-34. - Payment; returns. 
    Taxes levied under this article are due and payable when a return is required to be filed. Every taxpayer shall within the time specified, submit a return to the tax collector on the form prescribed by the tax collector. A return must be signed by the taxpayer of the taxpayer's agent. Returns of taxpayers are due to the tax collector each month on or before the 15th day of the month following the month in which the tax accrues. As provided in G.S. 160A-208.1, a return shall not be considered a public record and information contained in a return may be disclosed only in accordance therewith. 
(Code 1972, § 11-34; Ord. No. 2000.20, § 4, 7-12-2000) 
Sec. 94-35. - Taxpayer's records. 
    The taxpayer shall keep and preserve suitable records of the gross receipts received by such taxpayer in the conduct of business and such other books or accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of the tax for which such taxpayer is liable under the provisions of this article. It shall be the duty of the taxpayer to keep and preserve for a period of three years all such records of gross receipts and other books and accounts described. All records, books and accounts herein described shall be open for examination at all reasonable hours during the day by the tax collector or his duly authorized agent. 
(Code 1972, § 11-35; Ord. No. 2000.20, § 5, 7-12-2000) 
Sec. 94-36. - Forms. 
    The tax collector shall design, prepare, print and make available to all taxpayers operating within the municipal boundaries of the city forms and instructions for filing returns to insure a full collection of an and accounting for taxes due. The failure of any taxpayer to obtain or receive forms shall not relieve such taxpayer from the payment of the tax at the time and in the manner provided. 
(Code 1972, § 11-36; Ord. No. 2000.20, § 6, 7-12-2000) 
Sec. 94-37. - Situs of transactions. 
    The transaction giving rise to the tax herein levied shall be deemed to have occurred at the location of the entity from which the customer takes delivery of the vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 11-37; Ord. No. 2000.20, § 7, 7-12-2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-215.1(b). 
Sec. 94-38. - Penalties and remedies. 
    The provisions with respect to remedies and penalties applicable to the Local Government Sales and Use Tax, G.S. 105-463 et seq., as contained in G.S. 105-164.44, shall be applicable in like manner to the tax authorized to be levied and collected under this article, to the extent that the same are not inconsistent with the provisions hereof. The governing body of the city may exercise any power the secretary of revenue may exercise in collecting sales and use taxes. 
(Code 1972, § 11-38; Ord. No. 2000.20, § 8, 7-12-2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-215.1(f). 
Sec. 94-39. - Administration. 
    In addition to the provisions herein, the levy and collection of the taxes herein imposed shall be otherwise administered in the same manner as the sales and use tax as provided in G.S. 160A-215.1(d). 
(Code 1972, § 11-39; Ord. No. 2000.20, § 9, 7-12-2000) 
Sec. 94-40. - Authority. 
    This article is enacted pursuant to the provisions of G.S. 160A-215.1. 
(Code 1972, § 11-40; Ord. No. 2000.20, § 11, 7-12-2000) 
Chapter 95 - TREES 
ARTICLE I. - PURPOSE AND DEFINITION 

Sec. 95-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the planting, maintenance and removal of trees on municipally owned public property and rights-of-way within the city and on municipally owned property wherever located. In order to protect and conserve trees on public property and rights-of-way, this chapter provides for the pruning, treatment and removal of trees and shrubs as is deemed necessary by the city council. This chapter is also intended to provide for the trimming or removal of trees when they obscure street lights, interfere with utility lines, or constitute a hazard to pedestrian or vehicular traffic, or otherwise endanger the public health, safety or welfare. 
    Another purpose of this chapter is to encourage the protection of trees and express the city's intent to use trees to create a more natural and amenable human environment. This chapter is not intended to be punitive or cause hardship to any person who uses the utmost care and diligence to protect trees within the city or on city property. 
    This chapter shall further provide for the establishment of an advisory committee known as the tree board which shall be responsible for promoting trees and tree care throughout the city and for developing a city tree plan. 
(Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 10-19-2010) 
Sec. 95-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Master tree plan means a written document that guides the work of the urban forestry program. 
    Public tree means trees, shrubs, and bushes now or hereafter growing on any public street right-of-way or public land within Newton corporate limits. 
    Street tree means any tree, shrub, and bush on land lying within rights-of-way on either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the city. 
    Urban forest means the collection of shrubs, trees, vegetation, and associated natural features that make up the city tree canopy and the area required for its sustainable growth. 
    Urban forestry means the planning, establishment, protection, and management of trees, vegetation, and associated natural features, individually, in small groups, or under forest conditions within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 10-19-2010) 
Secs. 95-3-95-9. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TREE BOARD 

Sec. 95-10. - Creation and establishment. 
    There is hereby created and established a tree board for the city which shall consist of seven members who shall be citizens, and residents of this city. Such members shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council. Ex officio members may be appointed as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 10-19-2010) 
Sec. 95-11. - Terms of members. 
    The term of the seven persons to be appointed by the city council shall be three years except that the terms of two of the members appointed to the first board shall be for only one year and the term of two members of the first board shall be for two years. If a vacancy shall occur during the term of any members, his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion for the term. No member or alternate of any board, commission or committee shall serve more than two consecutive three-year terms, plus any unexpired or partial term to which any such member might be appointed to complete. 
(Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 10-19-2010) 
Sec. 95-12. - Attendance. 
    The term of office of any member of the tree board who shall be absent from three successive regular meetings or six regular meetings in any one calendar year shall automatically terminate, and a new member shall be appointed in the same manner as the original appointment to complete the remaining portion of the unexpired term of such member. 
(Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 10-19-2010) 
Sec. 95-13. - Compensation. 
    Members of the tree board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 10-19-2010) 
Sec. 95-14. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)	It shall be the responsibility of the tree board to study, investigate, counsel, develop, update annually, and administer a written master tree plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. Such plan will be presented annually to the city council and upon its acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan for the city. 
(b)	The tree board shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. 
(c)	The tree board shall, in addition, serve as an advisory board to the city council with the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)	Facilitate the planting, growth and protection of trees within the city; 
(2)	Foster the communication among the citizens of the city that would provide the needed protection of trees and to coordinate active measures to support their health and growth within the city; 
(3)	Conduct a tree inventory of existing trees along streets and on public property within the city; 
(4)	Investigate available grants, loans or contributions from other governmental agencies, public or private corporations, or individuals, and recommend the expenditures of any proceeds toward the accomplishment of the board's purpose; and 
(5)	Conduct continuing research, planning, and feasibility studies required to support the purpose stated herein. 
(6)	Review and evaluate existing tree related policies and practices as needed or requested. 
(Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 10-19-2010) 
Sec. 95-15. - Operation. 
    The tree board shall adopt rules for the transaction of its business and shall keep a record of its members' attendance and of its resolutions, discussions, findings, and recommendations, which record shall be a public record. The tree board shall set a regular schedule for meetings, and the chairman may call a special meeting upon request of a majority of members of the tree board. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 10-19-2010) 
Sec. 95-16. - Review of acts and decisions by city council. 
    The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the tree board. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the tree board to the city council who may hear the matter and make a final decision. 
(Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 10-19-2010) 
Secs. 95-17-95-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 95-20. - Public trees. 
(a)	The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the public right-of-way of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
(b)	The city may remove or cause or order to be removed, any publicly-owned tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electrical power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners, providing that the selection and location of such trees is in accordance with the guidelines for planting and spacing developed by the tree board. The tree board may reserve the right to approve any plantings that take place in right-of-way areas. 
(Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 10-19-2010) 
Chapter 98 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The city's Customer Service Policy Manual and Manual of City Specifications, referred to in this chapter, are not printed herein but are on file in the city offices. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 98-1-98-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CUSTOMER SERVICE 

Sec. 98-31. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed them by this section: 
    Applicant means any person(s) or entity requesting electricity, water, sewer and refuse service or any combination thereof. 
    Council means those officials elected to represent the citizens of the city. 
    Customer means any person(s) or entity purchasing electricity, water, sewer and refuse service or any combination thereof from the city. 
    Employees means the employees of the city charged with the responsibility of delivering services to the citizens and customers while ensuring good business practices and considering the needs and wants to the customers. 
    Family is defined as in section 102-7. 
    Good credit means no more than two delinquencies, no bad checks, no disconnections in the most recent 12-month period for residential customers and a 24-month period for commercial customers, and payments being made by the due date. 
    Tampering means unauthorized altering of the status of an electric, water, or sewer meter by noncity personnel for the purpose of receiving electricity and or water and sewer service or any combination thereof without paying for them. 
    Utility means the city utility department. 
    Utility service includes electricity, water, sewer and refuse or any combination thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 24A-1; Ord. No. 94.33, § 1, 7-12-1994; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002) 
Sec. 98-32. - Application for service. 
    The city reserves the right to require the applicant, before any utility service is provided to him, to execute an application or agreement for such service in a form prescribed by the city. Whether or not a written application or agreement is executed, the applicant, by accepting utilities from the city, agrees to be bound by the applicable schedule of rates and the terms and conditions as, from time to time, are in effect. 
(Code 1972, § 24A-2; Ord. No. 94.33, § 1, 7-12-1994) 
Sec. 98-33. - Requirements to be met by applicant. 
(a)	The city will be obligated to supply utility service to an applicant only when the following requirements shall have been complied with: 
(1)	The applicant must be the person(s) or entity who is either renting or purchasing, or who owns, the premises; 
(2)	The applicant must provide evidence of meeting the requirements of subsection (1) of this section, if the city requests it; 
(3)	The applicant must present valid identification with photo, if applicable, when requesting utility service; 
(4)	The applicant must not owe the city any outstanding street assessments, taxes, utility bills or any other charges; and 
(5)	A deposit must be made with the city in accordance with the city's Customer Service Policy Manual. 
(b)	The city may refuse utilities to any applicant failing to meet these requirements. 
(Code 1972, § 24A-3; Ord. No. 94.33, § 1, 7-12-1994) 
Sec. 98-34. - Deposit required; amount. 
    A deposit shall be required under the conditions and in the amounts set forth in the most recently adopted schedule of fees and charges for the city. 
(Code 1972, § 24A-4; Ord. No. 94.33, § 1, 7-12-1994) 
Sec. 98-35. - Exemptions from deposit. 
    Governmental entities, municipal resale customers and departments of the city shall be exempt from furnishing deposits. 
(Code 1972, § 24A-8; Ord. No. 94.33, § 1, 7-12-1994) 
Sec. 98-36. - Disposition of deposit upon termination of service. 
    When a customer has furnished a deposit to guarantee payment of utility bills and service has been terminated, such deposit will be applied to any unpaid charge or indebtedness due to the city for unpaid utility bills and the balance refunded. 
(Code 1972, § 24A-9; Ord. No. 94.33, § 1, 7-12-1994) 
Sec. 98-37. - Voluntary discontinuance of service. 
    In order to assure discontinuance of service at a time requested by the customer, notice to the city in advance of the proposed time of discontinuance shall be required. When a customer desires to discontinue service, he shall give notice to the city at least 24 business hours in advance, and the customer will be responsible for all service consumed within the 24 business hours following the time of his notice to the city. 
(Code 1972, § 24A-10; Ord. No. 94.33, § 1, 7-12-1994) 
Sec. 98-38. - Involuntary discontinuance of service. 
(a)	The city reserves the right to discontinue utility service to a customer at any time without notice, upon the occurrence of any one or more of the following events: 
(1)	Whenever reasonable grounds exist to believe that the customer is receiving electricity or water or sewer service without paying therefor or that the city's meter, wires, pipes, valves or other apparatus have in any manner been tampered with. 
(2)	Whenever the condition of the customer's premises does not meet the minimum housing standards of the city. 
(3)	Whenever the customer has denied an authorized city representative access to the city's meter, wiring or other apparatus installed on the customer's premises. 
(4)	Whenever it is necessary to prevent fraud upon the city. 
(5)	Whenever, after reasonable notification and warnings by the city of an inability to read its meter(s) because of vicious dogs, shrubs or other obstacles, the customer fails to correct the situation. 
(6)	Whenever one of the customer's checks given in payment of a bill is dishonored. 
(7)	Whenever a customer fails to pay a utility bill within the time required by this article. 
(8)	Whenever a customer fails to make a required deposit guaranteeing payment of charges for electric, water and sewer service or to increase his deposit as required by this article. 
(9)	Whenever a customer refuses legitimate access to his premises, or damage to or loss of property of the city on a customer's premises is suffered by the city as a result of the customer's actions. 
(10)	Unauthorized extensions of any utility service beyond the premises of the customer. 
(11)	Whenever, disconnection of utilities would eliminate an illicit discharge as defined by section 87-34. 
(b)	When it becomes necessary for the city to disconnect utility service to a customer for any one of the foregoing reasons, reconnection will be as provided in the most recently adopted customer service policy and procedures. If the reason for the disconnection is due to tampering, the customer will be required to pay the city, in addition to all other fees, for each occurrence, the following: 
(1)	A reconnection and tampering fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges; 
(2)	The cost of replacing a damaged meter; and 
(3)	The estimated unmetered and unpaid charges for usage of electricity, water or sewer. 
(c)	If a customer is receiving utility service at more than one location, service at any one or all locations may be discontinued if bills for service at any one or more locations are not paid within the time specified by this article. 
(Code 1972, § 24A-11; Ord. No. 94.33, § 1, 7-12-1994; Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 5-3-2011) 
Sec. 98-39. - Water leak policy. 
    When a customer has discovered a leak in the water supply line on the customer's side of the meter, it shall be the policy of the city to adjust the customer's bill, only after the leak has been repaired and only on conditions where the water lost through such leak would not have been discharged into the city's sewer system. Such leak must be verified by a city employee or a licensed plumber. In such case, no credit will be given for lost water. The customer will be given an adjustment in his sewer treatment charges for no more than three months in the same location. To compute such adjustment, the customer will be billed for the average sewer use during the past six months at the same location. 
(Code 1972, § 24A-13; Ord. No. 94.33, § 1, 7-12-1994) 
Secs. 98-40-98-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER AND SEWERS GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to own and operate water and sewer systems, G.S. 160A-311 et seq. 

Sec. 98-61. - Laying of lateral sewer or water lines. 
    Water or sewer laterals laid as a part of any water or sewer main improved shall be laid only to the property line. 
(Code 1972, § 25-1; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-62. - Meters, equipment, etc., to belong to city. 
    All meters, meter boxes, pipes and other equipment furnished and used by the city in installing any water or sewer connection shall be and remain city property. 
(Code 1972, § 25-2; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-63. - Maintenance of meters and other equipment. 
    All meters, meter boxes, pipes, and supply equipment, except those required to be furnished by particular users of water and/or sewer, shall be kept in good repair and working order by the city. The city may, at its discretion, make repairs and replacement of such equipment and charge the user for such repairs. All meters over one inch in size shall be calibrated and/or replaced by the city at least once every two years. The expense of such calibration and/or replacement shall be borne by the user. 
(Code 1972, § 25-3; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-64. - Injuring or interfering with water or sewer system. 
    No person, except those duly authorized, shall tap or take water or sewer service from any main or service pipe, hydrant or other fixture; tamper with, open or shut any fire hydrant; trespass upon the buildings or grounds of the pumping stations or in any way interfere with the proper operation thereof; deface or injure any main, hydrant, valve or any fixture or thing whatsoever belonging or pertaining to the waterworks or sewer system or in any way prevent the proper use thereof; climb upon or into the reservoir or ascend the water tower or tamper with any of its fixtures; break or obstruct any portion of any manhole, lamphole, flushtank or any part of any public sewer line; or obtain any water fraudulently or by misrepresentation. The members of the fire department may use the hydrants in case of fire or to wash the fire hose or to perfect themselves in the use of firefighting apparatus. 
(Code 1972, § 25-4; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-65. - Types of fees and charges. 
    Rates for use of the city's water and sewer systems shall be charged in the amounts set forth in the schedule of fees and charges for the city. 
(Code 1972, § 25-5; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 90.3, § 1; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002) 
State Law reference- Authority to fix and enforce rates, charges, etc., G.S. 160A-314. 
Sec. 98-66. - Pertinent provisions of chapter to be part of contracts. 
    All pertinent provisions of this chapter are hereby made a part of the terms and conditions whereby the city furnishes sewer or water service to any person or whereby the city makes any sewer or water connections or performs any work of any kind in connection with the furnishing of sewer or water service. 
(Code 1972, § 25-9; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-67. - Wasting water prohibited. 
    No person, upon an alarm of fire, shall neglect or refuse to shut off any fountain, lawn sprinkler or garden hose. No water tenant shall allow the water from any of his pipes or fixtures to be wasted, and such person shall give notice of any leaks in his pipes or fixtures to the superintendent, who shall cut off the water until he is notified that the leaks have been repaired. 
(Code 1972, § 25-10; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-68. - Swimming in reservoir. 
    No person shall bathe, wade, swim in or otherwise go into the waters constituting the lake or pond that is used by the city for its source of water. 
(Code 1972, § 25-11; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Secs. 98-69-98-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER AND SEWER CONNECTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to require connections, G.S. 160A-317. 

Sec. 98-91. - Required; backflow prevention. 
    Every person who owns a house and lot or building used for human habitation or occupancy, which lot abuts or adjoins a street or alley along which is located an accessible public sanitary sewer within 200 feet of such lot and an accessible water line within 300 feet, shall make water and sewer connections with his house, building or other place of human habitation or occupancy; provided, that no person shall be required to cross the private property of any other person to make such water or sewer connections. In lieu of a public sewer connection and where no public sanitary sewer line is accessible, a septic tank approved by the state board of health shall be installed. All connections made to the water system of the city shall be provided with adequate backflow prevention to prevent induction into the city water system of any materials, substances or fluids from the internal system of the user. 
(Code 1972, § 25-12; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-92. - Water-carried sewage facilities required. 
    No person shall build or remodel any structure used for human habitation or occupancy within the city which is not provided with water-carried sewage facilities. 
(Code 1972, § 25-13; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-93. - Connections to be made after mains completed. 
    Within 30 days after the time when any water main in any street is completed and ready for use, the owner of every abutting lot whereon water is supplied for any human use shall cause such lot to be connected with such water main. Within 30 days after the time when any sewer main is completed and ready for use, if a water main has also been installed in such street, the owner of any abutting lot which has thereon improvements for human occupancy shall cause a water closet and sink to be installed and connected with such sewer main and shall cause all other sewer facilities within such improvements to be connected with such sewer main; provided, that the owner of the premises shall be notified in writing by the city of the installation of such water main or sanitary sewer and shall have 30 days after such written notice within which to make the required connection. 
(Code 1972, § 25-14; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-94. - Application. 
    No connection shall be made to any sewer or water lateral until the written application therefor has been approved by the plumbing inspector, except in approved subdivisions or planned unit developments. 
(Code 1972, § 25-15; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-95. - Extensions of and connections to laterals. 
    Extension of and connection to water and sewer laterals of the city shall be made in accordance with the terms and conditions of the city's water and sewer extension policy, as outlined in article VII of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 25-16; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-96. - Separate connection required. 
    Every house or building abutting any water or sewer main and requiring a water or sewer connection shall be separately and independently connected. When two or more houses or units are connected with the same water or sewer lateral, a separate water meter and sewer tap shall be provided for each such house or unit. This section shall not apply to planned unit development. 
(Code 1972, § 25-17; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1) 
Sec. 98-97. - Connections outside city. 
    No connection of any water or sewer line or system outside the city shall be made to any part of the city water or sewer system without special permission, and every such connection permitted shall be made on such terms and conditions as prescribed by the director of public works and utilities. 
(Code 1972, § 25-18; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002) 
Secs. 98-98-98-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WATER SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-121. - Purpose. 
(a)	This article sets forth requirements for users of the city water system owned and operated under the provisions of G.S. 160A-311 et seq. 
(b)	This article provides for the regulation use of water through the issuance of permits to certain users and through enforcement of general requirements for the other users, authorizes monitoring and enforcement activities, assumes that existing customer's capacity will not be preempted, and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs of the system. 
(c)	This article shall apply to the city and to persons outside the city who are, by contract or agreement with the city, users of the city water system. Except as otherwise provided herein, the city manager shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 25-19; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 90.3, § 2) 
Sec. 98-122. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Capacity charges means those charges determined by the city as appropriate to reimburse the city for capital costs incurred in providing water service. 
    City means the City of Newton. 
    City council means the council of the City of Newton. 
    Consumption means water used, metered, measured, etc. 
(1)	Average consumption. Total use over a 24-hour period, as computed from use of an extended period of time, such as a year or longer. 
(2)	Maximum daily consumption. Maximum daily use, which shall be considered 125 percent of the average daily consumption established above, unless otherwise defined. 
(3)	Maximum monthly. Maximum monthly use, which shall be considered 105 percent of the average daily consumption times the number of days of operation in a calendar month, unless otherwise defined. 
(4)	Maximum rate of use. Maximum flow rate, which shall be considered 250 percent of average daily consumption in terms of gallons per minutes, unless otherwise defined. 
    Flow means measure of volume per unit of time, and a term interchangeably used with "use" and "consumption." 
    Gage means a city-approved measuring device. 
    Gallons per day (GPD) means the rate of gallons measured over a continuous 24-hour period. 
    Gallons per minute (GPM) means the rate of measured water flow in 60 seconds. 
    Meter means the city-approved metering device. 
    Metering point means the point or points designated by the city for water use and/or pressure determination. 
    Residential means noncommercial or nonindustrial water consumption. 
    Seasonal means chronologic periods where differing water consumption criteria may apply. 
    User means a water customer. 
    Volume charges means the charge made per unit of volume of water metered. 
(Code 1972, § 25-19A; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 90.3, § 2; Ord. No. 2002.31, 8-21-2002) 
Secs. 98-123-98-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 98-141. - Unauthorized use prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to use, without a city permit, water from the city water system. 
(Code 1972, § 25-22; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 90.3, § 2) 
Sec. 98-142. - Suspension of water service or permit. 
(a)	The city may suspend the water service when, in the opinion of the city, continued use may present an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health or welfare of persons or to the environment. 
(b)	Any person notified of a suspension of the water shall immediately stop use. In the event of a failure of the person to comply voluntarily with the suspension order, the city shall take such steps as deemed necessary to terminate use. 
(Code 1972, § 25-22A; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 90.3, § 2) 
Sec. 98-143. - Grounds for permit revocation. 
    Any user who violates the conditions of his water use permit or this article is subject to having his permit revoked. 
(Code 1972, § 25-22B; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 90.3, § 2) 
Sec. 98-144. - Damage to city equipment. 
    It shall be considered a misdemeanor to maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any equipment or materials belonging to the city used for the purpose of making measurements, tests or examinations and left upon the premises of a water customer. 
(Code 1972, § 25-22C; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 90.3, § 2) 
Sec. 98-145. - Violations; penalties. 
    Any user who is found to have violated an order of the city council or to have willfully or negligently failed to comply with any provision of this article, and the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder, shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each offense. Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. In addition to the penalties provided herein, the city may recover reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, court reporters' fees and other expenses of litigation by appropriate suit at law against the person found to have violated this article or the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder. In addition to such penalties, violation of the provisions of this article may result in the discontinuance of sewer service. 
(Code 1972, § 25-22E; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 90.3, § 2) 
Sec. 98-146. - Exceeding permitted use. 
    Any water whose water use exceeds the permitted rates of use stated in his permit shall pay, in addition to all other established charges for use of the water system, an excess use charge for each and every gallon of water exceeding the permitted limit. Such excess use volumes may be computed based on water meter records or other such techniques as deemed representative by the city. 
(Code 1972, § 25-22F; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 90.3, § 2) 
Sec. 98-147. - Falsifying information. 
    Any person who knowingly makes any false statements, representation or certification in any application, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this article, or the water use permit, or who falsifies, tampers with or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this article, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not more than six months, or by both. 
(Code 1972, § 25-22G; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 90.3, § 2) 
Secs. 98-148-98-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WATER SYSTEM USE 

Sec. 98-171. - Water to be furnished at metered rates only. 
    Water shall be furnished to consumers at metered rates only, except for fire protection. 
(Code 1972, § 25-20; Ord. No. 88.5, § 1; Ord. No. 90.3, § 2) 
Sec. 98-172. - Connection. 
(a)	All connections to the water system shall be made only upon application to and under the direction of the proper authorities appointed by the city manager. Such connection shall be only through an approved water meter installed in accordance with approved plans and by the use of such gate and check valves and such other safeguards as shall absolutely prevent any water from the pipes of any mill or plant from entering the city mains.
